Figure 1.5. The elephant in detail: Structure of this book's broader chapters.

Chapter topics in Part III include endogenous return effects; forward-looking value and carry measures; usefulness of survey data; tactical forecasting models; as well as seasonal, cyclical, and secular return patterns. The book closes with main investment lessons and two appendices: a section on world wealth (size of main asset classes) and a description of data series and data sources [8].

Given the book's ambitious scope, it may be too much to absorb in one reading. To allay this problem, each chapter is reasonably self-contained and the reader can cherry-pick the topics of interest.

Now, let us turn to Poet Saxe and this chapter's concluding reflections:

And so these men of Hindostan

Disputed loud and long,

Each of his own opinion

Exceeding stiff and strong,

Though each was partly in the right,

And all were in the wrong!

In an afterword, often omitted from recitations of his poem, Saxe reveals his hidden agenda: he is lampooning those (and there were many in his time) who engage in meaningless disputes about theology:

Moral:

So oft in theologic wars,

The disputants, I ween,

Rail on in utter ignorance

Of what each other mean,

And prate about an Elephant

Not one of them has seen!

There are enough theological disputes about finance and investing. Like many writers, I too have a preacher's passion, but I preach in an ecumenical church. This book stands against narrow-mindedness, inflexibility, and overconfidence in investing, and for humility, pragmatism, and diverse perspectives.

Despite such lofty goals, I hope you enjoy the read, learn a lot, and eventually find that the insights in this book make you a better investor.

# 1.6 NOTES

[1] I endorse greater use of survey data to help interpret market pricing. High stock market valuations could reflect optimistic cash flow growth forecasts or low discount rates while steep yield curves could reflect the market's view of rising short rates or a high required bond risk premium. Survey data can help make these decompositions if consensus forecasts are deemed representative of market views. Survey-based analyses of stock, bond, and currency prices often support irrational explanations for asset return predictability instead of time-varying risk premia.

[2] When discussing hedge funds (Section 11.4) I review the debates about alpha, (traditional) beta, and alternative beta as return sources. The boundaries are blurred. One definition of alpha is "the average return that cannot be explained by common risk factors." As more and more factors are added to models that explain fund returns, ever less scope is left for measured alpha. Yet, active managers argue that they are simply taking views against the market; if they are right they make money which should be deemed as alpha. Tensions naturally arise between these two mindsets. Investors into hedge funds are especially concerned about asymmetric strategies that involve selling various forms of tail risk insurance whose payoffs can look deceivingly alpha like. If the fund manager's "view" is that the stock market will not fall by more than  $10\%$  in any month (or that the real estate market will not fall in nominal terms or that yet another rare event will not materialize), even a manager without any forecasting skill can be profitable and collect fees for years before the tail event with large losses occurs.

[3] Every investing institution can debate (i) whether dynamic investment approaches—such as market timing, value tilt, or factor-based investing—are appropriate for it and (ii) whether these approaches should be coded in the benchmark or left for the active manager in the quest for outperformance. These questions are not so different from asking whether emerging market stocks, commodity futures, or hedge funds should be included in their allowable investment universe and even into the benchmark. The answers will certainly vary across institutions, depending on prior beliefs, resources, costs, and other considerations.

[4] These masterworks belong on every serious investor's bookshelf. Books by DMS and Ibbotson (including work with various coauthors) provide more underlying data than mine does; indeed, I use their data in some of my analyses. Both focus rather exclusively on historical average and period-to-period (say, annual) returns on traditional asset classes, though the authors have elsewhere expanded empirical analysis to other asset classes and investment strategies. My book distinguishes itself by its comprehensive coverage of asset classes and strategies as well as by its many perspectives to tackling expected returns. I also embrace "new" ideas, such as time-varying expected returns and investor irrationality, more than these other books do.

[5] Selectivity cannot be avoided. I emphasize some of my pet themes that are not yet part of the academic consensus, such as the impact of wealth-dependent risk aversion and lottery-type preferences on asset prices, the promise in market and/or factor timing, or the usefulness of survey data to assess real-time investor expectations. If any personal bias shines through more than the others, it is my preference for simple and liquid assets. Such assets are more transparent, often leading to better outcomes for end-investors. Sunlight is the best disinfectant, protecting investors against abuse.

[6] In competitive markets, realized returns reflect much more variability than expected returns. Yet, humans have a tendency to attribute any good past performance to skill or other persistent edge. We repeatedly get "fooled by randomness" when we equate ex post success with ex ante skills and underestimate the role of chance. This is true in many realms of life but especially with investing.

[7] Frustratingly for academic readers, I rarely show standard errors,  $t$ -statistics, or the statistical significance of my findings. This partly reflects my target audience, and partly my view that the time-varying nature of expected returns and various biases make standard statistical inferences inappropriate. I prefer to assess the consistency of a return series "in investment language" by reporting the Sharpe ratio (which is closely related to statistical significance) and by displaying cumulative performance graphs that I find particularly informative for experienced users.

[8] Personally, I love footnotes. I would also prefer to give too many credits and literature references in the text, explaining the intellectual history of each key idea. Finally, I was brought up to carefully document my data series construction. I have been advised that I am in a minority on all three counts. Thus, I try to shorten the book and improve its readability by minimizing notes (now "only" about 100 left), placing them at the end of each chapter. I make some references in the main text on the sources of ideas or empirical findings, but a longer list of references can be found at the end of the book. My data sources are only briefly listed under each exhibit, but Appendix B describes my data sources and data series construction in detail.

Source notes. Although I make some references in the main text, I leave most of them for the "Source notes' section at the end of each chapter. The reference section proper can be found at the end of the book. Given the wide-ranging topic of this book, even these source notes must be selective. On many topics, I refer to important recent works rather than to seminal works. Even if the new working papers are often specialized and have not been tested by time, interested readers can find in them references to both other recent works and the intellectual heritage of the idea.

Books closest to this work are Ibbotson–Brinson (1993), Siegel (1994), and Dimson–Marsh–Staunton (2002). This book is intended for professional investors and assumes much prior knowledge. For professionals wanting to learn about institutions, products, and analytical tools in diverse investment markets, I recommend the various handbooks edited or written by Frank Fabozzi. For retail investors, I recommend William Bernstein (2002, 2009), John Kay (2008), and Malkiel–Ellis (2010). Among finance textbooks, I recommend Bodie–Kane–Marcus (2008) for MBA level and Cochrane (2005a) for Ph.D. level, while the history of the interaction between academic and practitioner finance is best covered in Peter Bernstein's books Capital Ideas and Capital Ideas Evolving.

## 2

## Whetting the appetite: Historical averages and forward-looking returns

- I present some historical performance statistics for major asset classes and investment strategies, but I also highlight the pitfalls in using such data.
- Average returns across asset classes seem positively related to volatility and illiquidity. Bearing duration risk and emerging market risk were exceptionally well rewarded during the past 20 years, equity risk not.
- The results for 1990–2009 may be sample specific, reflecting an abnormally benign environment for certain asset classes. This problem can be mitigated by adjusting average returns for any windfall gains and by studying subperiod results and longer return histories.
- Historical average returns are particularly misleading measures of prospective long-term returns if expected returns vary over time and the past sample period includes a significant repricing. Forward-looking value indicators have their own limitations but are often superior proxies for expected returns.

Before delving into the terminology and theories of expected return determination in the next chapters, I provide some empirical appetizers. Chapters 2 and 3 focus on historical average returns over a 20-year window and over even longer windows. I emphasize the pitfalls in interpreting historical data. If you do study historical returns, as most investors do, this chapter reminds you of several skeptical questions you should ask.

I first summarize the performance of all major (and some minor) asset classes and a few exceptionally successful active strategies over the past two decades.

- The choice of my starting point (1990) is rather arbitrary, largely driven by data availability for certain strategies and factors. (Data for the principal asset classes go back much further.) Any such historical analysis is inherently sample specific, a problem for which I will suggest some remedies.
- One 20-year window gives only one historical data point to assess the prospects for the next 20 years. For any serious statistical analysis, hundreds of years of data would be needed. Chapter 3 turns to evidence over longer time spans, but data availability and quality deteriorate the further back we look, and structural changes may make older data irrelevant.
- Historical average returns can be especially poor proxies of future expected returns in a world with time-varying expected returns. I prefer ex ante measures of long-run expected returns, such as bond yields or earnings yields, and this point, indeed, is one of the key themes of this book.
- The reported returns may not have been achievable due to trading costs (which are especially significant for illiquid assets and for strategies with high turnover). Total nominal returns also ignore the detrimental impact of taxes and inflation.

Nonetheless, historical returns are a natural starting point of investment analysis, partly because humans are hardwired from prehistoric times to imitate successful actions and to learn from past experiences. Such hardwiring helped our ancestors survive and develop but it may work poorly or even be harmful in the domain of competitive modern financial markets. The disclaimer "past performance is no indication or guarantee of future results" seems overused but bears repeating because it goes against key evolutionary traits.

# 2.1 HISTORICAL PERFORMANCE SINCE 1990

Table 2.1 documents raw annualized compound average returns (nominal geometric means) and risk-adjusted returns (Sharpe ratios), as well as some risk statistics, for various investments over the period 1990-2009. The Sharpe ratio (henceforth SR) is the annualized arithmetic mean excess return over cash, divided by its annualized volatility; cash can be represented by the deposit rate (here) or by the Treasury bill rate (Chapter 3). Illiquidity estimates are subjective assessments of each asset's liquidity on a scale from 1 (liquid) to 5 (illiquid).

# Commenting on results for 1990-2009

- It barely paid to move from government bonds to either equities or to corporate bonds (i.e., the realized equity risk premium and credit risk premium were very low over this exceptional sample period).
- Global equities (the developed market index) even underperformed government bonds, dragged down by Japanese stocks whose bubble peaked just before our sample period started. Both U.S. and European stocks earned an annualized return over  $8\%$ , but Japanese stocks averaged  $-2\%$  returns each year.
- Among U.S. equity styles, small-cap value stocks fared best, while small-cap growth stocks fared worst.
- Emerging market equities and debt earned much higher returns than developed market assets.
- Duration risk was abundantly well rewarded, thanks to the persistent decline in yields. Global government bonds also benefited from diversification and earned the highest SR among traditional assets: 0.8.
- Corporate credit risk bearing was poorly rewarded. I will later return to one key exception, which is that buying short-dated (1-to-3-year) top-rated (AAA/AA) credits while shorting duration-matched Treasuries earned a high Sharpe ratio.
- Real estate markets ended up earning returns similar to those of stocks and bonds. Among other real assets, commodities and art underperformed while timber fared especially well.
- Actively managed venture capital, private equity, and hedge funds earned double-digit net returns, according to well-known indices (which may tend to capture the better performing funds and thus overstate industry returns).

Our sample began soon after the 1987 crash and, despite many financial crises over two decades, no comparable tail event occurred until 2008.

# Relating average returns to volatility and illiquidity

You do not have to be an efficient market purist to believe that long-run average return differences across assets reflect ex ante required rewards for bearing risk and illiquidity. I now take a first look into the determinants of return differentials across assets, starting from the classic mean variance relation as it was manifested in 1990-2009.

Figure 2.1 shows that the relation between average returns and volatilities is positive and reasonably consistent:

- So, across asset classes, volatility has been historically rewarded. (The same is hardly true within asset classes.)
- The link is not exact—assets don't line up perfectly on the regression line—nor should it be. Certain asset classes faced headwinds while others benefited from tailwinds during this sample, and volatility is not the only driver of expected returns. Some asset classes also benefited from active management and reporting biases. In particular, the returns of the three best-performing asset classes may be overstated due to survivorship and other biases [1].

Deviations from the fitted line in Figure 2.1 can be justified by many reasons: all volatility is not equal. One key characteristic missed by volatility is liquidity. Over the long run, less liquid assets should offer some compensation for their higher trading costs and lower trading/rebalancing flexibility. This reward is not constant over time. Illiquid assets tend to underperform during financial crises when liquidity dries up. Thus, illiquid assets should compensate investors for both the illiquidity and the systematic tendency to underperform in bad times. Moreover, less liquid assets tend to exhibit smoothed or stale pricing, which reduces their measured volatility and their correlations with other assets. Both positive illiquidity premia and the understatement of risk in the denominator of the Sharpe ratio calculation imply that we should observe higher Sharpe ratios for less liquid assets. Figure 2.2 confirms such a positive relation, based on my subjective estimates of illiquidity (with scale from 1 to 5, with 1 most liquid and 5 most illiquid). This empirical relation was even more positive before 2008. Yet, the apparent positive relation between illiquidity and asset class performance may reflect other factors than liquidity besides the various biases noted above.

# 2.2 SAMPLE-SPECIFIC RESULTS: DEALING WITH THE PITFALLS

The choice of 1990 as a starting year is somewhat arbitrary. When selecting any historical sample period, we make a stark all-or-nothing choice as to what historical data are relevant, obtainable, and representative of the future [2]. We effectively assume that the sample period is "neutral" with positive and negative unexpected surprises just washing out, without one-off windfall gains from changing valuations, and with just as many rare events occurring during the sample as the market had been expecting. We also rule out structural changes within the sample, time-varying expected returns, and systematic reporting biases. Do you still think the numbers in Table 2.1 are useful for forecasting after all these qualifications?

I mitigate the sample specificity of historical analysis by:

- using three endpoints (2009, 2008, and 2007) that give very different results:
- reviewing empirical evidence before 1990 for asset classes where good-quality data histories extend further back:
- adjusting average realized returns for sample-specific windfall gains from changing asset valuations:
- showing cumulative performance charts that illustrate subperiod fluctuations in asset returns since 1990.

# Contrasting different endpoints, 2009 vs. 2008 vs. 2007

Figure 2.3 shows that the historical reward to risk was even more perverse at the end of 2008 than at the end of 2009. Equities barely outperformed cash and clearly lagged longer Treasuries. Going back to 1990-2007, equities were still ahead of bonds but only modestly so when compared with longer histories. The lesson is that the selection of the sample period can matter a lot. Endpoints (or starting points) are especially misleading if they coincide with bubble or bust valuations (say, 2000 or 2008 for equities). The end of 2009 was fortunately a reasonably neutral period from the valuation perspective.

Figure 2.4. Many long-run Sharpe ratios plummeted in 2008. Sources: Bloomberg, MSCI Barra, Ken French's website, Citigroup, Barclays Capital, MIT-CRE, S&P GSCI, Hedge Fund Research, Cambridge Associates, own calculations.

Figure 2.4 contrasts long-run historical Sharpe ratios at mid-2007 and at end-2009. The 2008 carnage did real damage to many risky assets, despite the 2009 recovery. Global equities, credits, and commodities had not had particularly good SRs even between 1990 and the first half of 2007, but after the 2008 turbulence these SRs fell below 0.2. Private equity funds and (funds of) hedge funds, as well as real estate, had had high SRs but these all plummeted in 2008. The regression slope of long-run average returns vs. volatilities across numerous asset classes halved from  $0.4\%$  to  $0.2\%$  (not shown).

Up to 2007, embracing risk had especially paid off for strategies that resembled selling lottery tickets that pay off in bad times. Since really bad times did not materialize until 2007-2008, these skewed strategies performed so well that they attracted hot money, which further boosted returns:

- The archetypal strategy of this type is equity index volatility selling which profits from the normally steady gap between implied and realized volatilities. The strategy lost in September–October 2008 more than a decade's worth of profits. The long-run SR sunk from 1.3 to 0.4.
- The FX carry strategy and the aforementioned short-dated credit carry strategy also had SRs near 1 before the crisis and resemble a lottery-selling strategy; these too suffered dramatically in autumn 2008, and their SRs dropped.
- Not coincidentally, the hedge fund styles that gave the worst surprises in 2008 were also short financial catastrophe risk. Among the HFR hedge fund style indices, the largest declines in the long-run Sharpe ratio (not shown) were for convertible arbitrage (1.5 to 0.7), fixed income (1.5 to 0.9), and relative value arbitrage (1.9 to 1.3).

# Returns over longer histories (pre-1990)

Twenty-or-so years are an alarmingly short data window for forming views on long-term expected returns [3]. However, going back before 1990 would narrow the available set of asset classes—either no data or poor data quality in immature markets. Too long return histories also make it likely that we include data from a different regime (i.e., from before an important structural change). Despite these caveats, it is important to study long histories, and Chapter 3 thus contrasts the experience of the past 20 years with longer periods using extensive historical data.

Let us go back to Figure 2.3. On the left, the 20-year sample shows that global bonds outperformed stocks  $7\%$  vs.  $6\%$ . On the right, the 110-year sample shows that global stocks trounced bonds  $8.6\%$  vs.  $4.7\%$ . Which evidence do you give more weight to? The answer is not quite obvious because structural changes could make the recent past more relevant. However, a shorter history is also more likely to suffer from sample-specific effects, and I have already alluded to the secular yield decline and the Nikkei drag on global equities since 1990 [4].

# Adjusting for sample-specific valuation changes

The decades from the 1980s through 2007 were characterized by declining macroeconomic volatility and rising asset market valuations. The consequent windfall gains were presumably unexpected by investors; these gains boosted realized asset returns well beyond the ex ante returns that investors actually required. Government bonds benefited from this repricing more than most asset classes. I show next how to "neutralize a non-neutral sample" and adjust average returns to account for sample-specific (and presumably unexpected) changes in yields and risk premia.

U.S. Treasuries enjoyed great tail winds when market yields fell from over  $15\%$  in 1981 to  $8\%$  at year-end 1989 and then further to  $3.5\%$  at year-end 2009, thanks to lower inflation expectations and lower required risk premia on Treasuries. The cumulative windfall gains were roughly  $23\%$  (using the following approximation: yield decline of 4.5 percentage points times an average market duration of just above 5). Prorated to each of the 20 years, this repricing gain boosted the annual return of U.S. Treasuries by a tad over  $1\%$ . Without this repricing, the average annual return on U.S. Treasuries would have been  $5.8\%$  rather than  $6.8\%$  and the Sharpe ratio 0.32 rather than 0.53.

The emerging market debt spread over Treasuries fell from  $10\%$  in 1990 to  $3\%$  at the end of 2009, so these assets enjoyed even better tail winds. Depending on emerging debt duration, the average return was boosted by  $2\%$  to  $5\%$  by the repricing due to lower yields and spreads.

In contrast, U.S. corporate bonds and equities experienced mixed valuation changes during this sample period. Corporate spreads widened from  $1\%$  to  $1.5\%$  but yield levels fell together with Treasuries. The S&P 500 P/E multiple expanded from about 15 to 20 and dividend yield fell from  $3\%$  to  $2\%$ .

The above exercise of removing unexpected repricing gains should give us a better picture of what investors actually required ex ante during this sample period. The repricing-adjusted average return does not necessarily give us a good picture of what investors require now. Higher valuation ratios now would also mean that long-run expected returns are currently lower than their average during past decades.

The misleading nature of historical average returns is easy to see when we consider Treasury yields. Treasury investors understand that with current market yields below  $3\%$ , the high historical average return says little about future prospects. Repricing effects are much harder to see with other assets, such as equities, whose ex ante expected returns are less transparent and more ambiguous (see Box 2.1). Investors in equities and alternatives are thus more susceptible to naively extrapolating historical returns. When equity valuation multiples expand (and thus equity earnings yields fall), wishful investors hope that this change reflects rational expectations of faster future earnings growth instead of lower expected or required future returns. Empirical evidence suggests, however, that earnings yields are a better predictor of future equity market returns than of changing earnings growth rates.

# Box 2.1. Repricing effects (extract from my 2003 article in the Journal of Portfolio Management)

Bond investors understand better than equity investors the folly of extrapolating expected returns from past average returns drawn from a time when valuation levels have trended up or down. A rally—high realized returns—caused by falling discount rates will reduce feasible expected returns, rather than raise them. The example in Figure 2.5 shows that, between 1982 and 2001, 10-year Treasury yields averaged  $8.1\%$ , but the realized annual return was  $10.7\%$  because the downtrend in yields (from  $14.4\%$  to  $5.1\%$ ) added almost 3 percentage points of annual capital gains to the yield income. Using the  $10.7\%$  realized annual return or even the  $8.1\%$  average yield as an expected return proxy makes little sense now that the yield is  $5\%$ . The transparency of market yields prevents bondholders from harboring excessive return expectations after a long bull market. Figure 2.5 shows that the revaluation effect was even greater for equities. The earnings-to-price (E/P) ratio fell from  $12.4\%$  to  $4.0\%$  in 20 years; that is, the market paid 3.1 times more for a given amount of dollar earnings at the end of 2001 than at the end of 1981. This repricing explains almost 6 percentage points of the S&P 500's  $15.5\%$  realized annual return. Again the realized average return clearly exceeds the forward-looking return that was reasonable to expect in the 1980s, let alone now. Unfortunately, most equity investors may have focused more on historical returns than on forward-looking returns.

# Subperiod analysis

My preferred approach to studying return consistency across subperiods is to plot cumulative returns over time. Careful eyeballing of such graphs reveals performance for any subperiod of interest, especially if the graphs are in log scale so a given percentage return has the same impact irrespective of where it is on the Y-axis. Distinctions are even sharper if we subtract the common riskless return from all series and plot cumulative excess returns (cumulative outperformance over cash, here one-month deposit) (as in Figure 2.6).

Developed market equities enjoyed persistent rallies in 1993-2000 and 2003-2007 but lost about half of their value in 2000-2003 and again in 2008. Partly due to the Japan drag, the asset class ended up underperforming emerging markets, fixed income, and real estate. Emerging market equities gave investors a characteristically bumpy ride but delivered the highest returns. Fixed income returns were most stable, while real estate (in the U.S.) was the best-performing asset class between the mid-1990s and 2007 but then busted.

# 2.3 FORWARD-LOOKING RETURN INDICATORS

All historical return data may be beside the point if expected returns vary over time. One key theme in this book is that time-varying expected returns can make historical average returns highly misleading. The market's expected returns are unobservable. Yet, as I will show, forward-looking indicators, such as simple value and carry measures, can be useful proxies of long-run expected returns. They certainly give better signals than extrapolation of, say, past decade realized returns. In addition, there is mild evidence of long-run reversal patterns for certain asset classes—say, a decade with abnormally high returns on equities is more likely to be followed by a decade of below-average returns. Recall equity markets in 2000 following a two-decade rally when extrapolative expectations attracted many investors to invest just when expensive market valuations pointed to low prospective returns.

One common approach to estimating prospective returns involves relating current market prices to some sort of value anchor (one that can be as simple as historical average price, yield, or spread—or something more complex). The presumption is that market prices will gradually revert toward fair values that are proxied by such value anchors.

Carry captures an asset's income return over time or, more broadly, an asset's expected return if the capital market environment stays unchanged over time. Carry indicators are often related to value indicators but details differ.

A narrow use of the term "carry" may originate from borrowers, or those who are short an interest-bearing asset. The cost of borrowing, or of remaining short, is the interest rate (not the coupon rate, but the full yield to maturity including drift toward par). For investors carrying, or holding, a long investment position that is financed by borrowing, the carry of this self-financed position, or zero-investment position, is the difference between the yields of the long (investment) leg and the short (financing) leg. Most investments are income generating, providing yield-like returns, and investors typically prefer positive-carry trades. The term "(positive-) carry trading" refers to yield-seeking activities—buying high-yielding assets, financed by borrowing in low-yielding assets.

An expanded use of the term "carry" (to cover equities, commodities, etc.) includes any income return and other return (such as drift toward par, or roll up or down a futures curve; or broader payout yields to stock investors) that is earned when capital market conditions (such as the term structure level and shape) are unchanged. Note that, under this broader definition, carry is not always equal to income return or to yield, hence my use of the umbrella term "carry" to refer to all of these generically.

For equities, the earnings yield or earnings/price ratio (E/P)—the inverse of the price/earnings (P/E) ratio—is the most popular value indicator. The E/P is too broad a measure for income return because investors do not receive all earnings as income. The classic income return proxy, the dividend yield (D/P), is too narrow a measure because dividends are not the only way firms distribute cash to investors. (The dividend payout ratio has fallen since the 1980s, especially in the U.S., as many firms have replaced dividend payments with share repurchases.) For bonds, yield to maturity (YTM) or the internal rate of return is the traditional measure of value and income return. Yield spread is the classic relative value indicator in fixed income analysis, preferably adjusted for embedded options. Chapter 21 reviews these measures and their pitfalls.

Value or carry indicators are inherently narrow. Broader statistical forecasting models take into account many other sources of predictability in returns, such as momentum, volatility, and the macroeconomic environment. Another distinction is that statistical forecasting models typically have a short horizon, while value and carry signals give a longer term view on an asset's prospects. I will discuss some key predictors for equity market timing, duration timing, and credit spread timing in Chapters 8 through 10 and later drill into four specific predictability patterns in Chapters 12 through 15. Chapter 24 will give a slightly broader overview on forecasting models and dynamic trading strategies.

Figure 2.7 shows proxies of ex ante real yields of major U.S. asset classes over a very long historical period. Real yields are calculated as explained in Appendix B. Clearly, these yields vary a lot over time. If we take them at face value, the relative attractiveness of different asset classes varies drastically over time, suggesting that value-oriented market timing or tactical asset allocation strategies can be profitable. These indicators have their own shortcomings, but empirical evidence indicates that they do have some ability to forecast long-term asset returns.

Figure 2.7. Forward-looking real yields of U.S. equities, corporate bonds, Treasuries, and housing, 1900-2009.

The message from these valuation measures in early 2009 was that corporate bonds were historically cheap and government bonds historically expensive, while equities and real estate were rather normally valued. These relations normalized so much during the year that by early 2010 no glaring market opportunities were evident.

There are of course many other ways to predict asset returns—to be discussed in Sections 8.6, 9.6, and 24.4—but the contrarian approach shows promise and at least seems to do better than extrapolating long-run past returns. For an example popularized by Robert Shiller and John Campbell, Figure 2.8 shows how well smoothed earnings yields (the inverse of the P/E ratio, with 10-year average trailing earnings used instead of current year earnings, adjusted for inflation) have been able to predict subsequent multiyear equity market returns [5].

# 2.4 NOTES

[1] The venture capital (VC) asset class shows the highest average returns, perhaps partly reflecting various biases. (Moreover, PE fund and VC fund returns are based on internal rates of returns, so not quite comparable with the returns of other investments.) For anyone getting enchanted by the venture capital's  $16\%$  compound average return (and a higher arithmetic average return) between 1990 and 2009, I hasten to note that the annual return of  $39\%$  in the 1990s was followed by an annual return of  $-3\%$  in the 2000s.

[2] Even at best, historical means are just point estimates of expected returns that are subject to estimation error and in some cases also model error. Rebonato (2007) favors the use of Bayesian probabilities, which honestly reflect our uncertainty about expected returns, whenever conditions for using standard probabilities are not met. (In the Bayesian setting, estimation error is comparable with higher volatility.) Problems include time-varying expected returns, importance of rare events, a high ratio of forecast horizon to data history, and feedback loops (such as when observing past performance influences investors' asset demands and thereby future returns).

[3] If we make predictions of one-year returns, we may be able to make statistically significant inferences about excess returns using 20 years of historical data; whether such short-term forecasts are economically significant is a topic of debate. The Sharpe ratio is closely related to statistical significance. It is the ratio of mean excess return over its volatility, while statistical significance uses the same two variables plus sample size. (The standard error of a mean is  $\sigma / \sqrt{N}$  where  $\sigma$  is standard deviation and  $N$  is sample size. The denominator of a Sharpe ratio only includes  $\sigma$ .) Given a 20-year sample period, an asset's annual excess return is statistically significantly above zero if the Sharpe ratio exceeds 0.44 (i.e., the critical value of a two-sided  $5\%$  significance level is 1.95 and  $1.9 / \sqrt{20} \approx 0.44$ ). However, classical assumptions include an unbiased sample period, normally distributed asset returns, and constant expected returns—and the empirical validity of each of these is questionable. For example, if expected returns are not constant but vary over time, past average returns have less to say about future returns than do ex ante measures.

[4] Expressing the same contrast in Sharpe ratio terms, global bonds beat stocks hands down, 0.79 vs. 0.18, between 1990 and 2009, but global stocks beat bonds, 0.34 vs. 0.13, between 1900 and 2009. Note that the Dimson-Marsh-Staunton long history uses currency-unhedged bonds with very long maturities. Intermediate-maturity bonds tend to offer similar returns with lower volatility, and hedging the currency exposure has the same impact. Hedging poorly rewarded FX risk, avoiding the longest duration bonds, and diversifying across countries may give bonds a long-run SR similar to that of equities, 0.3-0.5. Any better SR for Treasuries probably reflects sample-specific yield trends.

[5] The predictive correlation of 0.55 may look impressive but long-horizon relations are often overfitted. Even if the relation is spurious, the high correlation of slow-moving indicators may have less investment value than fast indicators, with a correlation of only 0.10 over a one-month horizon (and thus an  $R^2$  of just  $1\%$ ; recall that explanatory power or  $R^2$  is just correlation squared), that offer many more trading opportunities. For readers who find these correlations low, I remind them that predictive correlations are always modest because realized short-term returns of risky assets largely reflect unpredictable news. A monthly predictive correlation of 0.10 is already a good basis for a profitable trading rule. Finally, this correlation—like the others presented in this book—is based on an in-sample fit and arguably overstates the investment value of the predictive correlation. A real-world investor in 1921 would not have known the full distribution of future earnings yields to come, while we know with hindsight that the series peaked at that time.

Source notes. This chapter's topics are discussed in more detail later in the book. The various works by Roger Ibbotson and Elroy Dimson, as well as their co-authors, are the best reference sources on historical returns.

## 3

## The historical record: The past 20 years in a longer perspective

- Any historical snapshot is sample specific. I try to put the experience of the 1990s-2000s in a longer perspective.
- Between 1990 and 2009, duration risk was well rewarded, credit and equity risk were not. Emerging Latin American equities, venture capital, and small-cap value stocks earned the highest average returns. Equity assets had modest SRs compared with various fixed income assets as well as active funds and strategies. Front-end Treasuries had the highest SRs.
- Asset return data from different sample periods are not really comparable even if the sample periods are quite long, but here are some empirical findings. Equities outperformed other asset classes; in particular, they outperformed bonds by  $4\%$  per year since 1900. Small-cap value stocks earned especially high returns, although trading costs reduced their paper advantage. The long-run reward for extending duration peaked at intermediate maturities at about  $1\%$ . The long-run credit premium was only  $0.3\%$  for investment-grade debt but over  $1\%$  for high-yield debt. Among rating classes, BB-rated debt—just below investment grade—performed best and CCC-rated bonds performed surprisingly poorly. Non-income-earning assets earned low long-run returns.
- The best long-run SRs were for front-end Treasury trades (that cannot be levered), high-turnover reversal strategies (before accounting for costs, which are substantial), short-dated credits, and active value/carry/momentum strategies. I require at least 30-year histories, so this comparison excludes hedge funds, private equity, timber, etc.
- Most of the analysis focuses on nominal returns but the last section presents evidence on real returns.

Although one of my key themes is to de-emphasize historical average returns when assessing prospective asset returns, I review asset return histories over 1990-2009 in considerable detail in this chapter. The purpose is not to use the historical returns as forecasts but simply to make the historical information available to the reader consistent. The choice of the 1990-2009 time frame was arbitrary, and was guided by the availability of data for a large spectrum of assets. In this chapter, I also contrast this 20-year experience with a longer history. Even such longer histories may have limited relevance in a world of time-varying expected returns.

# 3.1 STOCKS

Before dissecting equity market returns, let us recap the evidence on stocks vs. bonds, as made familiar by the works of Roger Ibbotson (with co-authors) as well as Dimson, Marsh, and Staunton. Figure 3.1 contrasts recent decades against a longer history. Bars show the 1990-2009 average returns for major asset classes, while the line shows average returns over a longer window. Only the values for the long sample are labeled. I use the same format in several of the graphs below.

Long Treasuries, corporates, and equities all earned average returns near  $8\%$  since 1990, smartly beating T-bills. Bearing duration risk was rewarded magnificently, while bearing further credit or equity risk was not. Small-cap value stocks were the best performers over both the short and the long history.

The history of the 1990s-2000s more closely resembles the 19th-century experience than it does that of the first nine decades of the 20th century. In the former, fixed income earned relatively high real returns and equities offered only a slim advantage over bonds, while earlier in the 20th century, stocks beat bonds by large margins. However, it bears repeating that the high realized returns of long-duration bonds in the past 20 to 30 years reflect windfall gains from the trend of falling yields.

Figure 3.2. Cumulative total nominal returns of global assets since 1900. Sources: Bloomberg, Dimson-Marsh-Staunton (2010).

For an even longer and more global perspective, Figure 3.2 plots (in log scale) Dimson, Marsh, and Staunton's world equity and bond returns since 1900. Over the long haul, equities handily beat fixed income. Global long bonds underperformed short-dated bills until 1990 due to capital losses from both rising yields and depreciation of non-U.S. currencies against the dollar. The graph also includes the interesting history of Japanese equities. After four decades of success (1900-1939, including strong performance during the Great Depression), investors in Japanese equities lost nearly everything after World War II, then recouped these losses and much more between the 1950s and the 1980s, and then faced the two "lost decades" after 1989. Still, the experience of Japan and, even more clearly, of Germany reminds us that hyperinflations can fully destroy fixed income wealth while leaving equity holders with a real nest egg.

Emerging market equities outperformed developed market equities since 1988 (when MSCI emerging market indices began) but they underperformed between 1976 and 1987 so badly that over the full 1976-2009 period for which Dimson-Marsh-Staunton (2010) have emerging market data, they lagged developed markets (9.5 vs.  $10.5\%$ ). Among regions, Latin American stock markets were by far the best performers in the 1990s and 2000s, partly because their valuations were so cheap after the 1980s' debt crisis. Japan lagged, having been the world's best performer from 1950 to 1989; our sample period begins just at the peak of the Nikkei bubble. Over the 110-year window, U.S. equities unsurprisingly earned the highest returns among major markets.

Figure 3.3 turns to U.S. industries. Over the past 20 years, energy and manufacturing offered the highest returns, but since 1926 the health sector performed best. Moreover, there is no obvious relation between industry volatilities and average returns.

The relative performance of both countries and industries, even over relatively long samples, seems to reflect period-specific developments. History simply tells us what happened in the past, with no information about what is likely to happen in the future. Thus, country-specific and industry-specific exposures are good examples of systematic risks that may not warrant any significant risk premium. That is, even if all stocks in the same country or in the same industry tend to move together, expected stock returns across countries or industries may not systematically differ—unless some countries or industries exhibit other characteristics that confer an expected return advantage on them.

Source: Ken French's website.

Value and size are the best known stock characteristics that are related to cross-sectional differences in average returns. Figure 3.4 shows that the average return ranks of the six size-sorted and value-sorted Fama-French portfolios are the same for the 1990-2009 and 1926-2009 periods (see the definitions of equity styles in Chapter 12 and Appendix B). Small-caps beat large-caps and value stocks beat growth stocks, on average. The small-value sector is thus understandably the best performer. Small-growth stocks—the proverbial lottery tickets—had the lowest average returns.

Table 3.1 shows that, on paper, momentum strategies fared even better than value, and short-term reversal strategies did even better. It is no coincidence that we find the highest gross returns in small-cap stocks and in high-turnover strategies such as short-term reversal and medium-term momentum. Recall that the numbers here exclude transaction costs, which would be substantial for these strategies. Incorporating trading costs would eat seriously into these paper gains. Ghayur et al. (2010) estimate that—net of costs—value and momentum strategies earned similar long-run returns. Others estimate that the double-digit gross returns of the short-term reversal strategy would have been negative after costs.

For evidence on the long-run stability of these relations, Figure 3.5 plots decade average returns over time. The graph shows long-short strategy returns (implicitly assuming that no net capital is invested), while in the table a cash return is added for style factors and active strategies (implicitly assuming the presence of cash collateral).

The average market premium was negative in  $15\%$  of these decade-long windows. Value and momentum strategies were even more consistently successful than investing in the overall market, earning negative returns only  $4\%$  and  $10\%$  of the time. The size premium fared the worst, with  $32\%$  of decade-long returns being negative. Excluding small-growth stocks from the small-cap universe would cut this fraction to  $20\%$ .

# 3.2 BONDS

Table 3.2 analyzes fixed income assets from various perspectives. The first point to note is the generally high level of average returns and SRs during the 1990-2009 period. The tail winds from falling yields were exceptional and color all the performance statistics. Table 2.1 showed that emerging market debt outperformed all the assets in Table 3.2, earning double-digit returns (11.5\%) but due to the short histories available for this market sector, I will not study it further.

Hedged global government bonds had an SR near one, partly due to the yield decline, but also because they enjoyed several structural benefits. Diversifying across several countries, hedging away volatile currency risk, and holding intermediate-duration rather than long-duration bonds all help reduce volatility. Adjusting for the annualized gains from sharp yield falls between 1985 and 2009, the SR for hedged global government bonds would be close to 0.5 instead of the 0.85–0.99 in Table 3.2, but this is still far higher than the 0.11 SR documented for a composite of unhedged long-duration bonds since 1900. Among major markets, German bonds fared the worst. Interestingly this is not due to the 1923 hyperinflation (because both the long holding of bonds and the implicit short position in bills lost everything, so these netted out in the hedged return). Currency hedging will be explained in Section 4.4.

Looking across investment-grade fixed income sectors in the U.S., corporates earned the highest returns between 1990 and 2009, while mortgages and agencies earned the highest volatility-adjusted returns. The new sector of asset-backed securities (and even newer commercial mortgage-backed securities for which data only exist since the late 1990s) gave the worst returns. Over long histories, long AA corporates outperformed Treasuries by  $0.3\%$  since 1926, while junk bonds outperformed Treasuries by about  $1\%$  since 1953.

Figure 3.6 assesses the reward for duration extension. For the 20-year sample, average returns rise steeply and monotonically with maturity. This period is unrepresentative and misleading for assessments of future returns as the downtrend in yields benefited all bonds but not evenly; for obvious reasons it benefited longest duration bonds most. Despite unexpected windfall gains, longest duration bonds have clearly lower Sharpe ratios than short-dated bonds, because of the higher volatility of long-dated issues. The SRs above one for short-dated issues reflects the fact that the excess return used for computing the SR is in excess of the one-month bill rate, at which only the U.S. Treasury can borrow.

Over a longer sample period, the reward for duration extension is more meager. If average returns were plotted vs. maturity, duration, or return volatility, the long-run relation would look more like a hockey stick, rising steeply into the 2-to-5-year range before tailing off. The period on which I focus (1952-2009) is driven by data availability—1952 is the first year for which we have return data for several maturity buckets. Conveniently, this data period also starts just after the episode during and after World War II when Treasury yields were regulated and were kept artificially low. Moreover, this period is broadly neutral in that yield levels were similarly low at the start and end of the sample. Later starting dates would imply windfall gains to bonds, just as we see for 1990-2009.

Indeed, more recent data suggest that "fallen angels"—HY bonds downgraded from IG—outperform original issue HY bonds (9.6 vs.  $5.7\%$  in 1997-2009). B-rated bonds still provide quite decent long-run returns but CCC-rated junk bonds have a poor long-run record, partly due to their high volatility and possible lottery ticket status.

The 1990s and 2000s were benign for all fixed income due to the falling yield trend, but in a relative sense many "spread products" (bond market jargon for issues exposed to credit and/or prepayment risk, selling at a yield spread over comparable duration Treasuries) did not fare as well as the total return series imply. Total returns also reflect yield level changes, and corporate bond indices benefited from their slightly longer duration than Treasuries amidst falling yields. Option-adjusted spreads and excess returns are better measures of spread products' ex ante and ex post return advantage over comparable duration Treasuries. Such data are available since 1989. The realized duration-adjusted excess return for IG credits was  $0.2\%$ , compared with the  $0.6\%$  total return edge. At the same time, HY bonds had a true (duration-adjusted)  $1.7\%$  excess return over Treasuries, but even HY bonds' cumulative advantage dropped to negative levels in 2002 and 2008.

Table 3.3 explores the degree to which various spread products really captured their ex ante yield advantage. Between 1990 and 2009, the Barcap (formerly Lehman) U.S. corporate index had a much wider average yield spread than agencies or mortgages; yet it earned a slightly lower realized return advantage (over Treasuries) than either of these two bond categories. Corporates' spread capture, defined as the ratio of the ex post return spread to the ex ante yield spread, was a poor  $21\%$  (27 bp excess return vs. 129 bp average spread). Where did the remaining 102 bp go? About 20 bp of the "missed" return can be explained by the 75 bp spread widening, the rest by default and downgrading biases and by index investors' poor selling patterns described in Chapter 10. (For the more benign 1990-2006 period, over which the corporate spread narrowed slightly, the spread capture was a still modest 44 bp of the 104 bp average spread.)

In contrast, U.S. agencies' fixed rate debt delivered even more than their 33 bp average spread; their spread capture exceeded  $100\%$ . There were no credit losses because, in the end, it was decided that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac were too big to fail. Mortgages captured only  $40\%$  of their 69 bp average spread. This may appear surprising because the spread over Treasuries narrowed during our sample, but the short embedded option in MBS really hurt when prepayment speeds and interest rate volatility rose. The last rows in Table 3.2 compare total returns across ratings and maturities. The combination of abundant duration reward and consistent credit reward gave high-rated 1-to-3-year credits an SR of 1.2. If we purge the duration effect, excess returns over duration-matched Treasuries are less impressive but still smoother than for long credits.

The thick line in Figure 3.8 illustrates the poor reward to risk from generic nongovernment risk taking in the 1990s and 2000s. At short maturities the excess returns were consistent until 2008. Duration extensions were very profitable thanks to the falling yield trend. Most active fixed income managers selected credit overweights rather than duration overweights as their preferred structural tilt, which gave them a rollercoaster ride in 2008-2009.

Among real assets, timber and crude oil futures earned the highest returns in the 1990s and 2000s. The three spot commodity price series as well as housing and art earned lower returns partly because they include no income [3].

The active funds and strategies that I study here had relatively high returns, perhaps overstated by selection biases. The SRs of illiquid assets are further boosted by understated volatilities. VC suffered a  $67\%$  drawdown since its 2000 peak, coming soon after a  $280\%$  gain in 1999, and remains deeply underwater. # 3.4 FX AND MONEY MARKETS

I focus above on dollar-denominated returns. The returns on non-dollar assets are mostly reported unhedged, in which case their dollar return includes the appreciation or depreciation of the foreign currency during the sample period. The returns on some foreign bonds are reported currency-hedged into dollars, in which case their dollar return also reflects the hedging cost, which is proportional to the money market interest rate differential across countries. Figure 3.11 shows that most G10 currencies appreciated against the dollar between year-end 1989 and year-end 2009. The Japanese yen spot exchange rate strengthened the most, by  $2.2\%$  per annum (cumulatively  $54\%$ ), which enhanced Japanese assets' dollar returns. Currency hedging would have boosted these assets' dollar returns even more because the hedger would have benefited from Japan's low interest rates (on average  $2.7\%$  lower than U.S. money market rates); thus the hedged investor would have netted an additional  $0.5\%$  per year. A pure currency investment into the yen mildly underperformed U.S. deposits (reflecting the net of spot rate appreciation and the average interest rate differential). Cash investments denominated in the currencies of all G10 markets other than the United States outperformed U.S. deposits. High-yielding currencies earned the highest average returns as their yield advantage was amplified by net currency appreciation. Many economists would consider this a surprising outcome because a high yield is usually interpreted as compensation for high expected inflation, which causes currencies to depreciate—not appreciate. However, during this period the high yields attracted capital and caused currency appreciation, while the feared inflation did not materialize. Carry strategy profits were not riskless, however; during financial crises the high-yielders suffered and the yen served as a valuable safe haven (see Chapter 13).

The near-monotonic link between average returns and average yields in Figure 3.11 is not evident if I redo the analysis with available G8 data since 1971 (when the Bretton Woods system collapsed); the high-yielding British pound and Australian dollar earned average returns similar to those of the low-yielding Swiss franc and Japanese yen. However, this approach only looks at long-run average yields to determine the results from holding static positions for decades; more dynamic currency carry strategies did make money between 1971 and 1989 as well as thereafter. Still, it is fair to say that the currency carry strategy benefited from tail winds in the 1990s and 2000s.

Average returns for one-month Treasury bills and one-month deposits between 1990 and 2009 are  $3.8\%$  vs.  $4.5\%$ . The 70 bp yield advantage, called the "TED" or Treasury-eurodollar spread, reflects credit and liquidity differences. Historically, the TED spread was narrow and stable for two decades until 2008 (see Figure 3.12). Money market credit spreads blew out in 2008 to levels not seen since 1982, and it is more impressive to see 200 bp to 300 bp spreads when Treasury bill rates are near  $1\%$  than when they are near  $10\%$  [4].

The average yield spread of private money market paper—whether repos (RP), commercial paper (CP), certificates of deposit (CD), or eurodeposits (ED)—over Treasury bills (TB) more than halved between the 1980s and the 2000s, despite spiking back to the 1981–1982 level in 2008 (see Table 3.5). It was a sign of the times that credit spreads widened only marginally following the September 11, 2001 terrorist strikes and the resulting temporary closing of some financial markets. As noted, there is a particularly attractive reward to risk when shifting away from short-dated Treasuries, but such opportunities cannot be arbitraged away by leveraged investors. Only the U.S. Treasury can fund at Treasury rates, while the holders of short-dated Treasuries can become less risk averse and more willing to accept non-Treasury risk. This indeed has happened—especially among central banks—resulting in significant spread narrowing and decline in the ex ante reward-risk tradeoff over time (until 2007). However, the 2007-2008 experience reminded investors that money market spreads widen at the worst possible times for financial institutions: during systemic crises. Only unprecedented central bank actions—"whatever it takes" was the motto—brought these spreads back down and caused a semblance of normality to return to financial markets.

Assets not covered in this chapter include many interesting cases with too short histories or poor data quality. Candidates range from the obvious to esoteric: emerging market debt, inflation-linked bonds, convertible bonds, interest rate swaps, credit derivatives, various structured products, exchange-traded funds, catastrophe bonds, distressed debt, and carbon trading.

# 3.5 REAL RETURN HISTORIES

The results above focused on nominal returns, as does most of this book. To compensate for what some readers might find to be insufficient emphasis on real returns, Table 3.6 presents the compound average real returns for many assets, decade by decade for the 110 years, and also for the 19th century (actually the 98-year period from 1802 to 1899) where possible. For the data shown, the 1980s and 1990s were among the best decades for most asset classes, while the 2000s were among the worst.

Table 3.7 supplements the above with information about average real price-only returns (i.e., excluding income, which was an important if not dominant source of return for both stocks and bonds in early periods). In addition, the exhibit shows valuation indicators and macroeconomic indicators. All real series are deflated by consumer price inflation (CPI), except for the ex ante 10-year real yield which uses long-run inflation expectations (based on survey data in recent decades and statistical estimates earlier; see Appendix B).

In this case, the roll return for gold was typically negative (reflecting contango) and exactly offset positive cash income. For crude oil futures, the roll return was only mildly negative (and indeed was positive until 2004), so the average futures return is higher than the average spot price change.

The LIBOR-OIS spread widened sharply during the 2008 crisis, but later narrowed back to  $< 10$  bp.

# 4

# Road map to terminology

I briefly review many definitions, distinctions, relations, and pitfalls. (Readers looking for the "meat" may skip this chapter and later use it as a reference section, as needed. Readers only interested in empirical evidence may jump all the way to Part II.)

4.1. Constant or time-varying expected returns?
4.2. Rational or irrational expectations formation?
4.3. Return measurement issues.
4.4. Returns in which currency?
4.5. Risk-adjusted returns.
4.6. Biased returns.

The terminology used to describe expected returns can be confusing. For most assets, expected returns are uncertain ex ante but they are also unknowable ex post. This is in contrast to realized returns, which are knowable ex post but which do not reveal what investors expected [1]. Realized returns are only one of many needed clues for inferring what investors might have expected. Since we cannot directly observe market expectations of returns or rates, we must infer expected returns from empirical data, including market yields or valuation ratios, past returns, and investor surveys, and from models.

An exception is the expected return on a default-free, zero-coupon government bond. The yield on such a bond is the return that investors expect—and in fact receive—if the bond is held to maturity.

When reading about expected returns, it is important to distinguish between time series predictability—variation in the expected return for a given asset class over time—and cross-sectional predictability—variation in the return expected at a given point in time for various different assets (e.g., for individual stocks within the equity asset class).

# 4.1 CONSTANT OR TIME-VARYING EXPECTED RETURNS?

Empirical research in finance since the 1960s has focused on cross-sectional differences in average returns, giving much less attention to the possibility of time variation in expected returns. Until 10 or 20 years ago, most academics and finance textbooks routinely assumed constant expected asset risk premia. Given constant expected returns, the best way to estimate expected future return is to calculate the sample average realized return over a long sample period [2].

During the 1980s and 1990s, empirical and theoretical research on time-varying risk premia began to challenge the assumption of constant risk premia in stock and bond markets. At the same time, behavioral finance suggested that boom-bust cycles may reflect time-varying sentiment and aggregate mispricing. Textbooks and academic consensus gradually shifted away from using the historical long-term average equity excess return as the best proxy for the future equity risk premium.

When expected returns vary over time, historical average realized returns reflect (i) historical average expected returns and (ii) historical average unexpected returns. The latter part includes the impact of changes in expected or required returns. This item can dominate realized returns if valuations change meaningfully during the sample period—especially when the sample period is relatively short.

Adjusting historical average returns for past valuation changes only gives us an estimate of past average expected return, not necessarily current expected return. The problem of misleading historical average returns is compounded because current expected returns are lower after valuation increases. If expected returns vary over time, prospective expected returns reflect current starting conditions—such as valuation ratios—and not historical average conditions. For example, the decades during which equity market valuations increased (the 1920s, 1950s, and 1990s) ended with historically high trailing returns but low expected returns.

# 4.2 RATIONAL OR IRRATIONAL EXPECTATIONS FORMATION?

Rational expectations have been a key paradigm in economics and finance since the 1970s. Rational investors make forecasts that correctly incorporate all available information, leaving no room for systematic forecasting errors. Early studies assumed a stable structural model whose structure agents know. More realistic hypotheses allow agents to rationally learn about evolving economic structures. This learning process over time could explain apparently biased expectations (predictable forecast errors) in empirical data.

Behavioral economics and finance have challenged this paradigm. Fully rational behavior requires quite complex calculations from *Homo economicus*, prompting the alternative idea that investors exhibit bounded rationality—rationality that is limited by their cognitive resources and observational powers. Psychological biases predict specific systematic deviations from rationality (to be discussed in Chapter 6). Two of the main examples of irrational expectations are excessive extrapolation and insufficient adaptation. That is, many investors expect past multi-year trends to persist more than they do, while they also underreact to recent news.

# Box 4.1. Terminology: expected vs. required returns

I find the term "expected return" potentially misleading because "market expectations" sometimes hardly conform to what most people expect. An extreme example occurred during the tech bubble when surveys pointed to exceptionally high subjective expectations of future equity market returns while objective forward-looking indicators pointed to exceptionally low future equity returns, given that market valuation ratios were so high. More generally, persistent market rallies may raise subjective return expectations (due to extrapolation bias) while they reduce objectively feasible returns (due to higher market valuations). Behavioral finance suggests that subjective (hoped-for) return expectations may well be negatively correlated with rationally objective return expectations.

Traditional academic terminology is based on the concepts of market equilibrium and rational expectations. In equilibrium (i.e., if price is equal to value), the expected return on the market portfolio, the return forecast for the equity market or any other market, should equal that market's required return. The expected return determines how high a return the market can feasibly supply, while the required return determines how high a return market participants (as a group) demand (in order to hold the amount of an asset that is on offer, so that markets clear and all assets are held). As always, market prices adjust to balance supply and demand. For example, if all investors suddenly require higher risk premia, current market prices of risky assets must fall.

Time variation in objectively feasible future returns may reflect mispricing caused by irrational expectations or sentiment fluctuations—but its origins could also be fully rational, reflecting risk premia that are time varying due to variation in the amount of risk in the market or in market participants' tolerance for risk. In the latter case, using the term "required returns" or "required premia" seems more fitting than "expected returns" or "expected premia".

# 4.3 RETURN MEASUREMENT ISSUES

Expected returns need to be viewed over some time horizon, in some base currency, and using one of many possible averaging and compounding methods. For meaningful comparisons, consistent methods should be used. (I remind technically oriented readers that simple returns  $[P_{t + 1} / P_t - 1]$  are additive across assets but not over time, whereas continuously compounded returns  $[\ln (P_{t + 1} / P_t)]$  are additive over time but not across assets.) My empirical analysis will focus on monthly return data, denominated in U.S. dollars, and typically measured as annually compounded returns. Fortunately, the main results are robust to using other reporting conventions, so they tend to hold generally.

Returns can be expressed in various ways. Raw nominal returns may be deflated to real returns, and this is typically done using the realized "headline" consumer price inflation rate. For yields and for forward-looking estimates of return, a survey-based or other measure of expected inflation may be more appropriate if such data exist. (The Treasury/TIPS break-even inflation rate is an example of a measure of expected inflation that is market based rather than survey based. Chapter 17 discusses pitfalls with this measure.) For excess return (risk premium) estimation the question "premium over what?" must be answered; the default answer is to subtract the return of a riskless money market asset, such as the Treasury bill rate, from the raw asset return, to arrive at an "excess return" or return premium. Many other types of premia can, of course, be calculated.

An important distinction is between arithmetic and geometric average returns. For example, the arithmetic average of two successive returns of  $+50\%$  and  $-50\%$  is  $0\%$ , but the geometric average is  $-13\%$ $\{[(1 + 0.5)*(1 - 0.5)]^{(1 / n)} = 0.87\}$ , where

$n =$  number of periods  $= 2\}$ . Basic finance theory, including single-period Markowitz or mean variance optimization and the single-period CAPM, requires that one use arithmetic means (AM) as inputs. However, most investors are interested in wealth compounding and this is better captured by geometric means (GM, also called compound average returns or compound annual returns). When I present historical evidence I focus on GMs, which show realized buy-and-hold returns. An asset's GM is always lower than its AM, and the difference is larger for high-volatility assets. An excellent approximation of the relation between GM and AM is:  $\mathrm{GM} \approx \mathrm{AM} - \mathrm{Variance}/2$ . For example, given  $20\%$  equity market volatility, annual variance is  $4\%$  ( $20\%$  squared) so the difference between AM and GM is roughly  $2\%$ . For more on the AM-GM gap, see Box 28.1.

# 4.4. RETURNS IN WHAT CURRENCY?

Most of my empirical evidence is expressed as dollar-based asset returns. For non-dollar assets this practice bundles local currency asset returns and exchange rate changes  $\left[(1 + H_{\mathrm{LC}})*(1 + \Delta \mathrm{FX})\right]$  into unhedged return. (The same is true for dollar assets from a Japanese investor's perspective.) It is often better to unbundle the two parts of unhedged returns and make separate active decisions on asset and currency allocation. Currency hedging can be done in various ways—selling expected FX proceeds using FX forward contracts, funding foreign asset purchases with foreign currency deposits, or directly buying non-dollar-denominated futures contracts. All these approaches keep the capital (and expected income) currency-hedged, with low trading costs. Only unexpected profits or losses would be subject to FX risk but this is inherently a second-order effect.

Consider an example where the U.S. equity market falls  $5\%$  and the dollar weakens by  $5\%$  against the yen. An unhedged Japanese investor holding U.S. equities would lose roughly  $10\%$  in yen terms  $(-9.75\%)$  return). A currency-hedged investor would lose something closer to  $5\%$  but not exactly  $5\%$ . The currency losses would not be exactly zero because investors can typically hedge only the expected proceeds of their investment, leaving the unexpected asset return exposed to FX risk. In this example, dollar depreciation makes yen-denominated losses slightly smaller, giving the currency-hedged Japanese investor holding U.S. equities a total loss of  $4.75\%$  in yen terms. The FX gain of  $0.25\%$ $(-5\%)$  of  $-5\%$  is an order of magnitude smaller than the FX loss for an unhedged investor. (In contrast, if the  $5\%$  U.S. equity market fall had coincided with  $5\%$  dollar appreciation, the unhedged Japanese investor would have ended roughly flat  $(-0.25\%)$  return) in yen terms, while the hedged investor's losses would have grown to  $5.25\%$  in yen terms.) Shortening the hedging horizon tends to improve hedging accuracy because the volatility of unexpected returns is reduced.

International comparisons are sometimes made using local currency returns. This convention can be misleading if inflation rates and nominal money market rates systematically differ across countries. For example, a  $10\%$  nominal asset return is much more impressive in a country with an inflation rate of  $2\%$  than in a country with an inflation rate of  $7\%$ . Because real short rates have been closer together across countries than inflation rates, it has been relatively fair to compare real returns across countries. Arguably the cleanest cross-country comparisons involve using common currency

These local excess returns are approximately equal to currency-hedged excess returns because the cost of currency hedging (the forward-spot premium in currency markets) is, by arbitrage, directly related to the money market interest rate differential across countries. It follows that, for any investor, the currency-hedged return of a risky foreign asset is well approximated by the sum of the investor's home currency deposit rate and the foreign asset's excess return over the foreign deposit rate.
