# 4.5 RISK-ADJUSTED RETURNS

Performance evaluation of any asset, strategy, or fund is increasingly done on returns that are somehow adjusted for the average risk taken. Adjustment for volatility is the most common risk adjustment, based on the logic that it would be "unfair" to compare, say, returns of  $4\%$  on two different assets with very different volatility levels. Specifically, the Sharpe ratio (SR) is the average excess return over the riskless rate of return (proxied, in practice, by a near-riskless money market asset) divided by the volatility of this excess return. The SR is a measure of volatility-adjusted or risk-adjusted return.

In the CAPM context, the optimal risky asset portfolio can be levered or de-levered through borrowing or lending of cash (i.e., short or long positions in cash). Investors can combine such cash positions with the optimal risky asset portfolio to reach any portfolio on the capital market line (which shows the maximum expected return for each volatility target). All portfolios on the capital market line have the highest attainable SR; in this sense maximum-SR portfolios are optimal. Conveniently, the SR is scale invariant (i.e., it cannot be increased by levering up the risky asset portfolio, while returns themselves—not adjusted for risk—can be [3]).

The SR has its shortcomings because all volatility is not equal. For example, since SR uses volatility as the risk measure, it ignores the distinction between systematic and diversifiable risks. According to classic portfolio theory, systematic risk such as equity market beta is more dangerous than idiosyncratic risk that can be diversified away. More modern critics point out that volatility does not distinguish between losses that occur in good or bad times or even between upside and downside surprises.

Another approach to risk-adjusted returns focuses on an asset's—or a strategy's or a fund's—contribution to portfolio risk as opposed to its standalone risk (a part of which is typically diversifiable). The classic Jensen's alpha is the intercept when regressing asset returns on equity market returns. More generally, alpha is the intercept of any risk factor model. Thus, alpha is risk-adjusted return where "risk" is some measure of the asset's contribution to portfolio risk. In the past 10 to 15 years, the Fama-French three-factor model—which contains size and value factors besides the market beta factor—has become increasingly popular among equity managers. Others use even more extensive multi-factor models including various industry and style factors for equities, another set of systematic factors for fixed income managers, and yet another set for hedge fund managers. Whatever risk factors are used, significant average loadings on any risk factor are viewed as evidence of a systematic risk tilt. As the number of factors increase, there is ever less scope for alpha (alpha being the return not explained by the various systematic factors included in the model).

Other risk adjustment methods also adjust returns for the higher moments of a distribution. (The mean—or expected return—and volatility are, respectively, the first and second moments of a distribution. The third and fourth moments measure the distribution's asymmetry and fat tails, respectively.) Yet other methods take into account varying liquidity characteristics, but none of these measures captures all the dimensions of risk.

# Box 4.2. Riskless return—no longer so clear

Short-dated Treasury bills are the traditional proxy for the riskless asset. Government debt issued in the government's own currency was long perceived as default free, thanks to a sovereign's taxation power and access to the printing press. Recently, markets have begun to reassess the risks of inflation, sovereign default, and currency depreciation in supposedly riskless assets. Inflation-indexed ("real") bonds are now available to eliminate inflation risk but they leave the investor exposed to default risk as well as FX risk for foreign buyers. The depreciation of the dollar since 2001 has made Treasuries anything but riskless for their main holders, the Asian central banks. At least the prospect of outright default seems more remote for the U.S. than for many other countries. The fewer chances a fiscally stretched government has to inflate, or devalue its debt through a depreciating currency, the greater is its temptation to default. In most countries, government bonds still have the lowest yields, but it is no longer unthinkable to see government yields rising above high-quality corporate yields. Indeed, even in developed markets, long-dated interest rate swaps are increasingly trading below government yields, and sovereign credit default swap spreads have dramatically increased since 2008.

The time horizon also matters. Long-dated Treasuries are arguably a more natural riskless asset for long-horizon investors, given the uncertain reinvestment rate for short-dated bills. Pension funds match their liabilities best by buying long-dated real or nominal bonds.

# 4.6 BIASED RETURNS

For many asset classes, returns may be positively or negatively biased over a given historical sample. For active asset managers with voluntary reporting, published returns are almost certainly upward biased. Section 11.4 reviews a host of selection biases such as survivorship bias and backfill bias in the context of hedge fund return databases, but similar caveats apply to the reported performance of other managers. Backtested results of active strategies also suffer from overfitting and data-mining biases, which also overstate published returns.

Whenever we observe exceptionally attractive historical returns, it is healthy to adopt a skeptical approach. The financial industry has limited incentives to emphasize this needed skepticism beyond printing required disclaimers, while our innate tendencies for extrapolation and optimism make most of us too easy prey for the upbeat marketing of past performance.

# 4.7 NOTES

[1] The distinction between realized (ex post) and expected (ex ante) returns should be crystal clear. Ex ante is Latin for "before the event", ex post is Latin for "after the event". Unfortunately, unevenly applied terminology can cloud the issue. For example, "high equity premium last year" sometimes refers to realized equity market return over cash or bonds. I prefer to use the term "realized excess return" instead—and only keep the word "premium" for ex ante measures.

[2] Long data histories are necessary to make statistically significant inferences of one-year returns, even assuming constant expected returns and no structural changes (see Note 3 in Chapter 2). Assessing the statistical significance of multi-year horizon returns would require much longer data histories.

[3] Sharpe ratio and relative return investors: The information ratio is the benchmark-oriented relative return manager's counterpart to an absolute return manager's Sharpe ratio. Information ratio is the mean excess return of a portfolio vs. its benchmark, divided by the tracking error (i.e., volatility of that excess return). Sharpe ratio is sometimes computed as the ratio of total return and its volatility, which is plain wrong; the return on a money market asset should be subtracted from total returns. The ratio of total return and its volatility is sometimes called the information ratio for hedge funds, on the premise that their benchmark is zero (motivated by the absolute return mandate).

Source notes. This chapter's topics are discussed in more detail later in the book.

# 5

# Rational theories on expected

# return determination

- New academic views on expected return drivers are more complex—and more realistic—than the neoclassical CAPM-and-efficient-markets view.
- Expected return differentials across assets reflect rational risk premia as well as market inefficiencies and supply-demand effects.
Instead of a single equity market factor, many rational risk factors as well as liquidity and skewness characteristics appear to influence expected asset returns.
- Risk premia are higher for assets or factors (e.g., equities, carry strategies) that fare poorly in bad times, whereas safe haven assets (e.g., government bonds) may even have negative risk premia over cash.
Expected returns can vary over time due to rationally time-varying risk or risk aversion and due to investor irrationality and sentiment.
- The efficient markets hypothesis has been challenged by various anomalies and financial crises but its main implication—that beating the market is very difficult—remains valid for most investors.

This chapter reviews the revolution in academic thinking about expected returns. Twenty-five years ago the consensus assumptions included

- a world with a single risk factor—the asset's sensitivity to the equity market (i.e., the CAPM beta);
- constant expected returns over time;
- investors care only about the means and variances of asset returns;
- frictionless markets; and
- efficient markets/rational investors.

The current view is more complex but also more realistic. There are

- multiple risk factors (whose required rewards ultimately depend on their covariation with "bad times"); time-varying risk premia;
- skewness and liquidity preferences (liking lottery tickets and liquid assets):
- supply-demand effects on asset prices; and
- market inefficiencies (due to investor irrationalities and/or market frictions).

Behavioral finance and investor irrationalities will be discussed in the next chapter. In case you are a practitioner thinking that rational investor models are irrelevant or obsolete, you may be tempted to skip this chapter and move directly to the next chapter.

Do this at your peril. You will miss many insights about the drivers of expected asset returns—which I try to make as palatable and practitioner friendly as I can. By reading both chapters, you may also find that the debate between the efficient market camp and the behavioralists remains healthy and has deepened our understanding of financial markets. Certainly, neither side has a monopoly on "the whole truth".

# 5.1 THE OLD WORLD

At the core of finance is always the present value relation that an asset's market price should equal its expected discounted cash flows. Investors set prices so that the marginal cost of an asset (its price) equals its expected marginal benefit (its expected discounted future payoff):

$$
\operatorname{Pr ic e}_{t} = \sum_{T = 1}^{\infty} E_{t} \left[ \frac{\text{Ca sh fl ow s}_{t + T}}{(1 + \text{Di sc ou nt ra te})^{T}} \right] \tag {5.1}
$$

There are different types of expected cash flows. The most common are promised coupons and principal payments of bonds, and dividends of equities:

- Government bonds are typically assumed to be default free; thus their expected cash flows equal promised cash flows. Other bonds have uncertain cash flows that may reflect the possibility of default (corporate bonds) or the future path of interest rates (mortgage-backed securities or floating rate notes), for example.
- For equities, the sum of expected cash flows crucially reflects the expected growth rate of dividends (or other cash distributions to the shareholder).
- Although equity cash flows continue in perpetuity and bonds may have very long maturities, this equation applies even without long holding periods. Since the next period's asset price should be priced in a similar fashion, the current price reflects the expected discounted sum of next period cash flow and next period market price.

However, the main topic of this book is the denominator of equation (5.1). At the market level, discount rates are just another name for expected returns. In equilibrium (i.e., if prices are fair), the discount rates investors require for holding assets are the expected returns they can rationally anticipate. Equilibrium market prices are set by supply and demand among investors applying equation (5.1).

The discount rate or the expected return contains both compensation for time and compensation for risk bearing. The return on the riskless asset reflects only the former; short-term Treasury bills are typically used to measure this riskless rate of return (in nominal terms). The expected excess return of a given asset over the riskless rate is often called the (ex ante) risk premium of that asset.

In the pre-Markowitz world, even uncertain cash flows were often discounted using the riskless discount rate. This approach implicitly assumes a zero-risk premium—a special case that applies only in an unrealistic world of risk-neutral investors. Understanding the various risk premia—"what influences expected asset returns or discount rates beyond the riskless rate?"—has been the main question in academic finance for the past 50 or 60 years. The capital asset pricing model (CAPM), originated by Sharpe, Lintner, Mossin, and Treynor, was the profession's first answer and, for a long time, the principal one [1].

The CAPM can be based on various sets of assumptions. I will not derive it formally here but show one traditional set of assumptions (that can later be relaxed):

- one-period world (this implies a constant investment opportunity set and constant risk premia over time);
- access to unlimited riskless borrowing/lending and tradable risky assets;
- no taxes or transaction costs (i.e., frictionless markets);
- investors are rational mean variance optimizers (only caring about means and covariances can be motivated by normally distributed asset returns or by a quadratic utility function); and
- investors have homogeneous expectations (all agree about asset means and covariances; all investors see the same picture).

These assumptions ensure that every investor holds the same portfolio of risky assets, combining it with some amount, positive or negative, of the riskless asset (this latter amount depends on the specific risk aversion of a given investor). Moreover, these assumptions lead to the conclusion that the holdings just described are optimal. Finally, in equilibrium, market clearing requires that the risky asset portfolio demanded in common by all investors equals the market portfolio of risky assets.

The CAPM's asset-pricing implication is that assets with a higher sensitivity to the market [2] should offer a higher expected return—see equation (5.2), which is a simple rendition of the CAPM. Why? Investors require compensation for the risk each asset contributes to their portfolio—not for accepting an asset's standalone risk. In a CAPM world where all investors hold the same market portfolio of risky assets, assets with higher market beta contribute more to portfolio risk:

$$
\text{Ex pe ct ed as se tr et ur n} = \text{Ri sk le ss re tu rn} + \text{As se tb et a} * \text{Ma rk et ri sk pr em iu m} \tag {5.2}
$$

While the CAPM's assumptions, including the single-factor idea, turned out to be too restrictive, one broad insight in CAPM remains valid in most new models: only systematic risk is "priced" in the sense that it influences expected asset returns. Realized returns reflect both common (systematic) risk factors and asset-specific (idiosyncratic) risk. Risk premia compensate investors for systematic risk that cannot be diversified away, whereas idiosyncratic risk can be diversified away and does not warrant any risk premium [3].

# Box 5.1. Risk-based expected returns

As an illustration of a risk-based model of expected returns, the next graph shows what expected excess returns CAPM would imply for various asset classes if we use a global equity index as the risk factor. (This kind of across-asset-class analysis is hardly the most common use of CAPM. CAPM is mainly applied for single stocks or actively managed portfolios and uses the local equity index as the "benchmark" or market index.)

Even apart from the CAPM's theoretical shortcomings, simply estimating asset betas and the market risk premium is difficult. In Figure 5.1, I estimate betas using monthly data from 1990 to 2009 and assume a global market risk premium of  $4\%$  (over deposits). Each asset's expected excess return is, by CAPM assumption, proportional to its beta. Only relatively liquid asset classes are included because illiquid assets have notoriously understated betas.

The graph is only illustrative. Serious practitioners use more complex risk models with several factors and have more advanced techniques for estimating betas. Finally, despite the theoretical appeal of CAPM, the empirical relation between betas and realized average returns is weak.

# 5.2 THE NEW WORLD

# 5.2.1 Covariance with "bad times" is the key

The CAPM was a beautifully simple theory but it became clear over time that it could not explain the observed behavior of asset markets. So academics began to relax the model's various simplifying assumptions. The parallel to the evolution of modern corporate finance research from the Modigliani-Miller theorems is clear.

There is little consensus as to which extension to the CAPM is most needed, so I cover here several strands of literature. In the new thinking on expected returns, multiple systematic factors, time-varying risk premia, skewness and liquidity preferences, supply-demand effects, market frictions, and investor irrationalities can all play a role [4]. (No single model can capture all of these features. Theoretical models need to be analytically tractable and they should be parsimonious. My survey will be neither.)

Despite the diversity of new models, at least the rationally oriented academic literature retains one key idea in its core, albeit subtly different than in the old world. The asset price still equals expected discounted cash flows, but in a world of uncertainty and time-varying expected returns, equation (5.1) needs to be generalized. Using the new terminology:

$$
\operatorname{Pr ic e}_{t}^{i} = E_{t} \left[ S D F_{t + 1} * x_{t + 1}^{i} \right] \tag {5.3}
$$ where SDF is the stochastic discount factor; and  $x$  is the payoff (cash flow) for asset  $i$  [5]. The term "stochastic" in SDF emphasizes the uncertainty in time-varying discount rates. But the great intuition is that SDF is an index of "bad times" and that the required risk premium for any asset (or a risk factor) reflects its covariation with bad times. Investors are willing to pay more—accept lower expected returns (i.e., lower risk premia)—for assets that tend to do well in bad times. Conversely, investors require higher risk premia for assets that tend to suffer in bad times. Here is a fundamental generalization of equation (5.2) for any risk premium or ex ante excess return:


$$

\text{Ri sk} \quad \operatorname{pr em iu m}_{t}^{i} = - \text{Co va ri an ce} (\text{As se te xc es sr et ur n}_{t + 1}^{i}, S D F_{t + 1}) \tag {5.4}

$$

The million dollar question is, of course, how to define bad times. Investors care about more than just low market returns. Formally, bad times are periods when investors' marginal utility (MU) is high—when an extra dollar in their pockets feels especially valuable. I might paraphrase U.S. Supreme Court Justice Potter Stewart's famous comment about pornography: bad times are difficult to define but "I know it when I see it."

# What kinds of environments imply high marginal utility?

- Consumption-based asset-pricing models associate bad times with negative consumption growth rates. The intuition of consumption smoothing is powerful: an extra dollar when we are hungry is worth more than when we are satiated [6].
- Recessions are often used to proxy for macroeconomic bad times. Periods of rising and/or high unemployment, rising and/or high inflation, or unexpected monetary policy tightening are other macroeconomic states that may be associated with high MU.
- Although neoclassical models do not emphasize this, it seems plausible that financial crises are important "high MU" environments, especially if financial institutions have a major role in setting asset prices. If we can equate bad times with stock market losses we get back the old CAPM, but "bad times" are likely to be more multi-dimensional. Sometimes other aspects of financial crises—a bond or housing market selloff, vanishing liquidity, de-leveraging spirals, a breakdown in financial intermediation, spiking volatility, high correlations that limit diversification—boost MU even when stock markets are relatively stable.
- The worst times are characterized by both financial and economic turbulence. Table 5.1 lists some periods that, in Justice Stewart's spirit, were manifestly bad times. One might formalize the definition but there is no (academic or practitioner) consensus on how to do this. All 20th-century recessions could qualify but the period of the Great Moderation was characterized by the absence of severe economic downturns and, instead, an abundance of periodic financial crises. The last two rows highlight episodes where major financial turmoil triggered depression fears—echoes of 1929—but Fed easing and/or bailouts saved the system yet again (and over time gave rise to ever greater risk taking).

The implications for asset pricing and expected returns are huge:

- On one hand, some safe haven assets like government bonds are not only "good diversifiers". They diversify best just when diversification is most needed (1998H2, 2001–2002, 2007H2–2008) and other diversifiers fail, they hedge equity markets best when equities are suffering most, and they benefit from "flight-to-quality" flows during financial crises. Safe haven assets may well warrant negative risk premia (i.e., expected returns below the riskless rate [7]).
- On the other hand, various strategies with asymmetric payoffs (positive carry trades, selling volatility and correlation, buying AAA credits vs. government bonds) may be even riskier than their negative skew and fat tails imply. The key point is the timing of losses: many such strategies effectively sell (not buy!) lottery tickets that pay off disproportionately during financial crises, just when MU is high. Thus these strategies face losses just when the losses are most painful. The coincidence of losses could reflect similar fundamental (tail) risk exposures but also liquidity-induced and positioning-induced correlation spikes (the latter were especially apparent in 1998, 2007, and 2008).
- I show empirically that many strategies with the best Sharpe ratios since the 1980s are of the second type. Their covariance with MU is high: they tend to lose money in bad times. This feature can largely explain their high Sharpe ratios. It is harder to explain the performance of government bonds since the 1980s as an equilibrium outcome, given the combination of a high Sharpe ratio and a wonderful diversification/hedging role. As noted, the high in-sample Sharpe ratios of Treasuries over that time frame likely reflect windfall gains from unanticipated yield declines. Note that the Sharpe ratios of Treasuries over periods ending in the early 1980s were very poor, reflecting windfall losses from unanticipated yield increases—a mirror image of the situation from the early 1980s to the present.
- Many practitioners define risk as unexpected losses, thereby ignoring the environment in which losses occur. In contrast, for academics, the timing of losses can determine riskiness as much as the amount of losses does (correlations matter more than volatilities).


# 5.2.2 Multiple risk factors

Since we cannot empirically identify one "true" factor for bad times, it is tempting to use multi-factor models. Robert Merton's Intertemporal CAPM and Stephen Ross's Arbitrage Pricing Theory introduced multi-factor models to finance theory as early as the 1970s. The empirical Fama-French three-factor model, developed in the early 1990s, has probably replaced the CAPM as the most popular factor model for equity investors.

Recall that, according to the CAPM, the  $i$ th asset's expected excess return,  $E_{t}(r_{t + 1}^{i})$ , is a product of its market beta,  $\beta_t^{iM}$ , and the market risk premium,  $\lambda_t^M$ , so that:

$$

E_{t} \left(r_{t + 1}^{i}\right) = \beta_{t}^{i M} \lambda_{t}^{M} \tag {5.5}

$$

$\beta$  is the amount of systematic risk in any given asset (thus, it varies across assets); and  $\lambda^M$  is the market risk premium that is common to all assets. We can further say that  $\lambda^M$  reflects both the amount of risk in the overall market (e.g., stock market volatility) and the price of risk (investor risk aversion).

Not surprisingly, CAPM's stance that "only market risk matters, all other risks can be diversified away" proved too restrictive. Empirical studies as early as the 1960s indicated that there are other common risk factors (e.g., industry factors) that are so systematic that they cannot be fully diversified away. It was still possible that such additional factors driving realized returns would not influence expected returns (i.e., these risk factors might not "be priced" in the sense of having nonzero risk premia), so the CAPM prevailed. However, over time academics and practitioners came up with a string of anomalies—evidence of dissimilar long-run average returns across stock portfolios that were inconsistent with the CAPM. The tide really turned when the seminal Fama-French (1992) study showed that a "value factor" and a "size factor"—actually the book-to-market ratio and market capitalization as equity characteristics, respectively, rather than factor sensitivities—could explain the cross-sectional variation in average equity returns better than a "market factor" could. Even worse for the CAPM, the cross-sectional reward for bearing beta risk appears to have been negligible or negative in recent decades.

If there are several common factors that generate undiversifiable risk, then a multifactor relation holds. If there are  $K$  systematic factors, the  $i$ th asset's expected excess return reflects its factor sensitivities  $(\beta^{i_1},\beta^{i_2},\ldots ,\beta^{i_K})$  and the factor risk premia  $(\lambda^1,\lambda^2,\dots ,\lambda^K)$ . For illustration, here is a simple two-factor case ( $K = 2$ ) with equity market risk and inflation risk. The expected excess return for any asset equals its equity beta times the equity risk premium plus its inflation beta times the inflation premium:

$$

E_{t} \left(r_{t + 1}^{i}\right) = \beta_{t}^{i_{1}} \lambda_{t}^{1} + \beta_{t}^{i_{2}} \lambda_{t}^{2} \tag {5.6}

$$ where  $E_{t}(r_{t + 1}^{i})$  is the expected excess return of asset  $i$ ;  $\beta_{t}^{j}$  (beta) is asset  $i$ 's sensitivity to factor  $j$  (here,  $j = 1$  is equity market, and  $j = 2$  is inflation); and  $\lambda_{t}^{j}$  (lambda) is the factor risk premium (market price of risk) for factor  $j$ .

Realized per-period excess returns for any asset can be expressed as a sum of the two systematic exposures (products of the asset's factor sensitivities and factor returns), plus an uncorrelated residual term (the part unexplained by the systematic factors). Realized factor returns contain both expected and unexpected components  $(\lambda + F)$ .

Within the SDF framework, if we assume that the SDF is linearly related to a set of common risk factors, then asset returns can be described by a linear factor model. Moreover, the idea that the risk premium depends on covariation with the SDF (bad times, high-MU periods) also applies to the risk factors—not just to individual assets. Different sources of return uncertainty can have different market prices.

If we view bad times as an underlying concept, the sign/size of each factor's market price of risk reflects its covariance with this meta-concept. Alternatively, we can treat different dimensions of bad times (negative growth, high inflation, financial crisis, illiquidity spiral, high volatility/correlations, etc.) as distinct factors. Each factor defines a different, though overlapping, set of high-MU periods that the average investor cares about. Investors who bear these priced factor risks effectively supply insurance to other investors against enduring losses in bad times and earn a factor risk premium as a compensation for this.

# Which factors?

Anything goes? Multi-factor models could include any factors, since theory gives limited guidance. Intertemporal (multi-period) models provide some direction. Merton's Intertemporal CAPM implies that priced factors other than market beta should hedge against future changes in the investment opportunity set. If investment opportunities vary over time, required returns also depend on assets' covariation with future investment opportunities. Merton suggested the long bond rate as one natural candidate factor, since all investors are exposed to the risk that they will not be able to invest at current rates.

Empirical models are theory-free representations in which factors are chosen to fit empirical asset return behavior; thus they are more prone to data-mining bias even if they may be justified with some economic logic. For example, the Fama-French value factor may reflect pronounced distress risk and the size factor may reflect illiquidity—though competing rational and irrational explanations exist. Both theoretical and empirical models serve a purpose. Empirical factor models are statistically better at explaining the cross-sectional and time series variation in asset returns, but economic models couched in theory may explain why any factors that are identified earn their risk premia.

Empirical models relate average returns to certain risk factor sensitivities (covariances) or directly to certain asset characteristics (value and size as noted above, carry, duration, or credit rating; etc.):

- One way to identify risk factors is to examine which factors are effective at explaining realized return variation over time and then to determine empirically if these factors are cross-sectionally "priced"; that is, if assets with high exposures to the candidate factor have significantly different average returns from assets with low exposures to that factor.
- Although it may seem even more ad hoc to use asset characteristics instead of factor sensitivities, the former are directly observable and might be less noisy measures of true factor risk exposures than historically estimated factor sensitivities.
- Often both approaches work empirically. For example, illiquid stocks have higher average returns than liquid stocks; separately, stocks whose returns covary more closely with a systematic "liquidity factor" (i.e., stocks with high-liquidity betas) have higher average returns than stocks with lower liquidity betas.

Factors with a strong theoretical basis include aggregate consumption growth (extensively studied for 30 years, with limited empirical success), investment growth (for production-based asset-pricing models) [8], as well as overall labor income growth and idiosyncratic job risk (recall that for many people the return on human capital is more important than the return on financial capital).

Equity factors that are primarily empirical include the last two of the three Fama-French factors (market beta, value, size) and often momentum as a fourth factor (driven by return evidence rather than by any economic risk story). The list could be extended, given growing evidence of cross-sectional return predictability, using indicators like return reversals (both short term and very long term), volatility, liquidity, distress, earnings momentum, quality factors such as accruals, and corporate actions such as asset growth and net issuance. Beyond equities, sensitivities to major asset classes (interest rate risk and credit risk in fixed income, and housing, oil, and dollar risks) are the most obvious factors to consider. The inflation factor is especially important for bonds, and liquidity for other assets. This chapter will not cover asset-pricing theories tailored for particular asset classes, such as government bonds (term structure of interest rates), credits, real estate, commodities, and currencies. I will briefly discuss such theories in Chapters 8-13.

# 5.2.3 Time-varying risk premia

Single-period models such as the CAPM indirectly imply constant expected returns over time. Other, more complex economic models often assume that volatilities and other risk measures are constant over time, and the most popular utility function implies constant relative risk aversion. No wonder, then, that for a long time academics were happy to assume constant risk premia and to estimate them using long-run average historical excess returns.

Things started to change in the 1980s. Diermeier-Ibbotson-Siegel (1984) made an early and largely ignored, but prescient, attempt to introduce time-varying risk premia from a purely theoretical standpoint. They argued that, in the indefinitely long run, stock prices could not grow faster than earnings, which could not grow faster than GDP adjusted for net new issues. The risk premium is the growth rate of earnings, plus the dividend yield, minus the riskless rate. Since all these variables are dynamic, the risk premium is time varying.

However, empirical evidence drove most of the change in thinking. It became increasingly obvious that ex ante real interest rates were not constant. Robert Shiller (1981) challenged the prevailing paradigm with evidence of excess volatility in financial markets. These patterns hint at irrationality but could be rationally justified with time-varying risk premia (because discount rate variation is another cause of volatility, in addition to the variation of expected cash flows that Shiller focused on). Elsewhere, academic journals began to fill with models of time-varying volatilities, while the introduction of stock and bond option markets confirmed that implied volatilities vary over time. Long-horizon studies presented evidence of mean reversion in stock prices, although it turned out that such long-horizon analysis is plagued with econometric problems. Fama-French (1989) documented countercyclical patterns in expected returns for both stocks and bonds, in line with required risk premia being high in "bad times" such as business cycle troughs. Although the focus soon turned to cross-sectional expected returns across equities, new evidence of predictable time variation in stock and bond returns was uncovered through the 1990s. Near the turn of the millennium, the equity market boom and bust reinforced the view that expected returns vary over time—for rational or irrational reasons. Practitioners became much more interested in ex ante return measures such as valuation ratios or dividend discount models. Several studies of the equity risk premium also shifted the academic focus from historical average returns to more forward-looking measures.

On the theoretical side, multi-period models make it plain that constant expected returns are a special case—albeit one that has the benefit of analytic tractability. Some early models made an ad hoc link between the risk aversion coefficient and equity market returns or the current health of the economy, but only habit formation models (discussed below) could formally derive wealth-dependent risk aversion (WDRA) from consumption utilities.

Theoretical models that imply time-varying risk premia can be quite complex. As an empirical shortcut, conditional (point-in-time) multi-factor models have become popular ways of allowing time-varying risks or time-varying risk aversion. In conditional models,  $\beta$ s (factor sensitivities) or  $\lambda$ s (factor risk premia) can be specified as linear functions of any set of predictors (conditioners) that are assumed to be in investors' information sets.

# Time-varying risks

Rolling estimates of second moments (historical volatilities, correlations, and factor sensitivities) are simple proxies of ex ante risks. In the past 20 years, academics have tried to improve on them by developing theoretical models of stochastic volatilities, simple linear models that predict future volatilities with a set of conditioners, more complex regime-switching models, and most importantly, a variety of so-called GARCH models. Opening up the acronym GARCH, to read "generalized autoregressive conditional heteroskedasticity", scares many investors, but the main idea is simply that volatility is not constant but varies predictably over time. Initial models focused on the idea that volatility comes in clusters—large shocks tend to be followed by large shocks and uneventful periods by more of the same. Despite persistence, volatility tends to gradually decay to a "normal" level from abnormal highs or lows. We have seen this pattern occur repeatedly in the financial market turmoil of 2007-2010. Extensions to GARCH-based volatility estimates included longer memories and return asymmetries (higher equity volatility in down markets, interest rate volatility depending on the rate level, etc.). GARCH models were also broadened to estimate ex ante correlations and factor sensitivities.

Time-varying risks are natural predictors of time-varying risk premia. However, models that link conditional volatilities and conditional mean returns have had limited success. Other empirical attempts to uncover a positive risk-reward relation between conditional equity market volatility and subsequent equity market return have had mixed results. While it is clear that high volatility tends to depress current equity prices, it is not clear that high volatility predicts above-average near-term returns for the equity market. I will describe some of this time series evidence in Chapter 19 as well as evidence on the cross-sectional relation between volatilities and equity returns.

# Time-varying risk aversion

The Fama-French (1989) evidence that expected stock and bond returns are especially high near business cycle troughs is exactly in line with the "covariance with bad times" idea. In Section 5.2.1, I expressed this idea as a cross-sectional prediction: assets that perform especially poorly in bad times should offer higher risk premia than assets that help us through bad times. In a time series context, we might then expect to see generally higher ex ante risk premia in bad times such as cyclical troughs or financial crises. However, this idea is not consistent with the widely used CRRA (constant relative risk aversion) utility function where risk appetite is independent of the investor's wealth level. (This utility function is widely used because it is mathematically tractable—not because it is realistic.) Only by incorporating a subsistence level into this utility function can we make risk aversion and required risk premia time-varying. When investors are closer to a subsistence level, any losses become less tolerable (see Figure 5.2).

Formal models are quite harsh in that agents really must ensure that they don't fall below the subsistence level or they face extinction (the academic term is "infinite negative utility"). In developed economies, subsistence level is not really linked to starvation or other causes of physical extinction, but to the (still painful) loss of the standard of living one is accustomed to. Despite this caveat, to me the insight that people or institutions become more risk averse when they become poorer captures something essential in investor behavior. In an institutional setting, breaching a subsistence level might have an analogue in the institution's bankruptcy, a trader reaching his or her terminal stop-loss limit or the point of an unaffordable margin call, a pension fund's minimum acceptable funding ratio, or a financial intermediary's binding capital constraint.

The presence of a broadly defined subsistence level makes investors' relative risk aversion vary with their wealth level and prompts them to act like someone trading a portfolio insurance strategy. When people feel wealthy (have a high cushion over the subsistence level) they can afford to take large risks. But if their wealth falls close to the subsistence level their risk aversion rises exponentially and they must shift their holdings to the riskless asset. Because falling aggregate wealth pushes many investors simultaneously closer to their subsistence levels, wealth-dependent risk aversion (WDRA) can have highly self-reinforcing effects on asset prices, especially crashes. Greater risk appetite after rising wealth and greater risk aversion after falling wealth creates a feedback loop (a virtuous or vicious circle) that contributes to boom-bust cycles and that makes asset returns more predictable and volatile than they would be had CRRA been a realistic assumption about investor utility.

![](https://cdn-mineru.openxlab.org.cn/result/2025-11-22/aa485235-5155-4ade-b88b-be1df0035d75/9e04811cf816690ab3716199a55d9a6249066c73208110c947d7d533c18d45d2.jpg)

Figure 5.2. Stylized illustration of wealth-dependent risk aversion.

However, the idea of WDRA is hard to model in a tractable fashion, especially in a multi-period context. The Campbell-Cochrane (1999) paper, "By force of habit", describes the best known finance model that exhibits WDRA. Habit formation captures the idea that past living standards influence the utility we derive from current consumption. Habit can be expressed as a time-varying subsistence level. Campbell and Cochrane model the subsistence level as a weighted average of past consumption, in the spirit of habituation or adaptation. Consumers derive utility from surplus consumption (excess of current consumption over subsistence level) and become exceedingly risk averse when this cushion becomes small.

In a broader context, habit formation and a time-varying subsistence level have evolutionary origins in human adaptiveness. People can adapt to new situations partly because their expectations adjust over time based on past experiences (both their own and neighbors' living standards). This is the best explanation of the apparent puzzle that various surveys find little change in self-reported happiness over the past half a century while material standards of living have dramatically improved [9].

The Campbell-Cochrane habit formation model is exceptionally successful in explaining various empirical puzzles, including the observed predictability (countercyclical time variation) in stock and bond market excess returns. Habit formation models imply changing tastes (for risk) over time. Rationally oriented economists tend to dislike the assumption of changing tastes, while behavioral economists embrace this idea (e.g., wealth-dependent market sentiment which would be hard to distinguish from WDRA).

It is important to understand that if time-varying expected returns reflect rational variation in risk premia, it does not follow that every investor should try to take advantage of them. For most investors these fluctuations do not give opportunities for utility-enhancing active trading because periods of high expected returns coincide with bad times and abnormally high risk aversion. However, a minority of cool-headed investors who in some relevant characteristics differ significantly from the market (long horizon, deep pockets—Warren Buffett and sovereign wealth funds come to mind) may be well served by contrarian market-timing strategies or at least by a disciplined rebalancing regime [10].

Unfortunately, the theoretical literature on time-varying risk premia is largely separate from the studies explaining the cross-sectional variation in expected asset returns. Fama's (1991) survey called for a coherent story that (1) relates the cross-sectional properties of expected returns to time variation in expected returns, and (2) relates the behavior of expected returns to the real economy. The search is still on—and some answers may need to be found outside the rational paradigm.

# 5.2.4 Incorporating skewness preferences

One way to extend the single-factor CAPM is to relax the assumption that people only care about mean and variance. The idea that people have skewness preferences (they are willing to pay up for lottery-type payoffs or for downside protection) is one of the key themes of this book. A growing literature studies the observed asymmetries in asset returns as well as their pricing implications (including pricing of options whose payoffs are inherently skewed).

If the SDF is linearly related to both market return and its variance, we get a three-moment conditional CAPM where expected asset returns reflect their conditional covariance with market return and with market variance (conditional co-skewness). In this model, the key aspect of skewness is not asymmetry in the standalone returns of a given asset but its contribution to the market portfolio's skewness (i.e., the co-skewness of the asset with the market). All else equal, people prefer assets that tend to earn high returns during volatile markets and thus make their portfolio more positively skewed (lottery ticket like). Such assets are rare, however, and people are willing to pay a high price for this characteristic. Conversely, people dislike negative skewness and require extra ex ante reward for holding assets—often volatility selling or carry trades—that perform poorly during volatile markets (and thereby make their portfolio more negatively skewed).

More behavioral considerations need to be invoked to explain the reward for assets' standalone skewness. Some authors simply assume that investors prefer assets with lottery-like payoffs while others argue that weighting of low-probability events can make skewness "priced". More on these questions in Sections 6.2 and 19.4.

# 5.2.5 Investor irrationality and rational learning

The next chapter covers investor irrationality in detail; here I make brief remarks on rational learning. Rational expectations, a key paradigm in economics and finance since the 1970s, has been increasingly challenged over the past decade. Rational expectations involve making an optimal forecast that uses all available information—there should be no systematic (predictable) forecasting errors. Rational investors have correct beliefs about the probability distribution they face (which implies "Bayesian updating" when processing new information) and make decisions like expected utility maximizers. It is common to assume a stable structural model whose structure agents know. More realistic hypotheses allow a time-varying structure and agents rationally learning about it. Such settings can explain the observed predictability of markets or apparently biased expectations, such as the well-known phenomenon in which investors underpredicted inflation in the 1970s and then overpredicted it in the 1980s. One need not resort to irrationality to explain these behaviors.

Brav-Heaton (2002) stress the mathematical similarity between behavioral finance models (investors who are irrational but possess correct information about market variables and economic structures) and learning models (investors who are completely rational but possess substantially incomplete information). The similarity is not just a coincidence but is related to the limits of arbitrage. Both in theory and in the real world, irrationality and incompleteness of information may be highly correlated. Where information is more complete, arbitrage opportunities are often taken advantage of, and irrationality-induced anomalies are less likely to survive.

# 5.2.6 Other determinants of expected returns

# Supply-demand factors

In economic theories supply and demand are central concepts, but in neoclassical finance theories they are not, thanks to arbitrage arguments. Arbitrage between assets that are perfect substitutes makes demand curves for specific, non-unique assets flat (horizontal). Thus the CAPM implies virtually flat demand curves for individual stocks because their diversifiable risk can be ignored (investors act as if they were risk neutral with regards to diversifiable risk). The market will price assets so that the expected returns on assets with similar risks are equal. If any particular asset should offer a higher expected return due solely to the increase in the quantity outstanding, investors will soon arbitrage away such profit opportunities. Arbitrage is possible because assets are "not unique works of art" but have close counterparts in other assets or mixes of other assets (Scholes, 1972). If there are perfect substitutes and frictionless markets, buying a high-expected-return asset while selling a substitute with a lower expected return constitutes a riskless arbitrage.

Subsequent empirical studies disputed the notion that perfect substitutes exist. Demand effects may play a key role in explaining time-varying risk premia, given the lack of substitutes for market risk exposures. Even the substitutability of single stocks can be challenged. A key example is the S&P 500 inclusion effect—the finding that new entries to the S&P 500 index experience a sudden and persistent price jump, presumably due to new buying pressure from index funds. Shleifer (1986) argued that if stocks have horizontal demand curves, no price impact is expected, but if demand curves are downward sloping, the rightward shift in the demand curve implies a sudden price increase, consistent with the evidence. Later research shows that the degree of substitutability varies (some stocks to be included have close counterparts, while others have much lower correlations—and thus have greater arbitrage risk). Stocks lacking close substitutes experience higher price jumps upon inclusion into the S&P 500. Still, index funds are expected by their investors to hold every stock in the S&P 500 index and some price pressure effect should be observed for any stock added to that index, no matter how many close substitutes the stock has.

These findings are interesting by themselves but they also have a broader message. If asset demand curves slope downwards (due to imperfect substitutability), shifts in asset supplies can influence prices and expected returns. Scarcity may boost current asset prices and reduce expected returns while abundance may do the opposite. Arbitrage does mitigate the supply-demand effects on asset prices and expected returns (especially among stocks with close substitutes) but because market frictions exist and arbitrage is not riskless, it does not fully eliminate them.

# Supply effects—examples

- Shorter run supply influences are especially notable for commodities that lack substitutes. A sudden shortage can cause sharp upward spikes in certain commodity prices.
- Another setting where scarcity may be important is the case of riskless assets where financial intermediaries cannot affect the net supply of demanded assets.

$\bigcirc$  Persistent fiscal surpluses, bond buybacks, and the prospective scarcity of Treasuries widened U.S. swap-government spreads to record-wide levels in 2000-2001, especially for ultra-long bonds. In the United Kingdom, long gilts became even more expensive due to supportive supply and demand factors.

- The most actively traded bonds often become "special" in the repo market, having financing rates 100 bp or more below general collateral rates, when "shorts" cannot borrow sufficient amounts of the bond.
- Even with stocks, there are occasions where an issuer has enough monopoly power to create (deliberate or accidental) scarcity. A well-known example is the Palm/3Com case, in which, near the peak of the dot.com mania, 3Com spun off its subsidiary Palm, selling  $5\%$  of its shares in the open market and promising the rest later. Palm instantly acquired a greater total market capitalization than its corporate parent 3Com, implying that the stub (3Com ex Palm) had a negative value. The Law of One Price clearly did not apply. Too few shares of Palm were available for arbitrageurs to take advantage of the opportunity (to sell Palm shares and buy 3Com shares, earning a large riskless profit). Once further Palm shares became available, this anomaly disappeared.

# Demand effects—examples

- Demographic developments may have a significant impact on asset prices but the results are controversial. The high proportion of prime-age savers (40 to 60-year-olds) in the population may have contributed to the 1990s "baby-boomer rally" in the stock market. Similar considerations have led to fears of falling prices for risky assets when baby-boomers retire.
- The savings glut story was one key explanation of the "conundrum" of low bond yields in the 2000s. Some controversial estimates suggest that foreign investor (mainly Asian central banks) demand for U.S. Treasuries reduced Treasury yields by more than 100 bp and other bond yields (close substitutes) by somewhat less.
- New assets may be structurally cheap until they find their natural home. Investor demand for inflation-linked bonds was quite limited following their introduction in 1997. The U.S. Treasury's hopes of cost savings—avoiding the inflation risk premium by issuing "real" rather than nominal bonds—were soon quashed. Inflation risk premia apparently had become tiny by 1997 and in the early years TIPS had to offer a large illiquidity or novelty premium to attract investors. Gradually investor interest in TIPS grew and the illiquidity/novelty premium decayed. Yet in 2008 de-leveraging and scant institutional demand made TIPS again very cheap for a short while.
- Investor positioning matters, especially during de-leveraging episodes. However, commentary about overcrowded trades is often too simplistic. Some forget that tautologically for every buyer there is a seller, so net active positions always amount to zero. When desired net buying wanes, market prices need to fall to attract new buyers. More meaningfully, overcrowding refers to situations where levered traders—the least reliable asset holders—have concentrated positions or where the whole financial market or a certain sector is exceptionally levered. In such situations, any trigger may lead to a mass rush toward the exit and to vicious cycles of liquidations and further price falls. A liquidity drought is the possible final outcome of such a cycle.
- The wide yield gap between Treasury debt and top-rated money market deposits or corporate bonds used to be one example of market segmentation caused by investor regulation or preferred habitats. Another example is the kink between the yields and long-run average returns of BBB-rated and BB-rated bonds—the borderline between investment-grade and speculative-grade ratings. Many investors are only allowed to hold investment-grade bonds; this constraint seems to boost the long-run return of BB-rated bonds.
- Market segmentation effects may be even more pronounced across countries given that the liberalization of foreign capital flows is incomplete. The full integration of all countries into global markets is a hoped-for outcome, not a reality.

# Market frictions and illiquidity premia

The impact of supply-demand factors—and of investor irrationalities—on asset prices is made possible by market frictions. Frictions related to illiquidity, funding constraints, and trading costs, as well as counterparty risk, agency concerns, and other information problems can be first-order important, as the 2008 experience shows. Bearish expectations, elevated risk, and risk aversion do not alone explain the distressed price levels of securitized bonds and other assets. Many financial intermediaries and investors became forced sellers as market frictions prevented them and other investors from taking advantage of good deals or nearly riskless arbitrage opportunities. Opportunities that appeared compelling over the long horizon could not be taken due to the possibility that further de-levering and related mark-to-market volatility would make the investment positions unsustainable over the short run.

A diverse literature on market frictions explains why asset prices might deviate from fair values or respond sluggishly to new information. However, few asset-pricing models relate asset risk premia to market frictions such as funding and liquidity constraints. Garleanu-Pedersen (2009a) propose a model in which the CAPM risk premium is boosted when binding funding constraints make capital scarce, while Acharya-Pedersen (2005) have adjusted the CAPM to include liquidity-related premia.

Illiquidity is the most important market friction. Early studies of liquidity premia focused on the cost (rather than the risk) of illiquidity—they observed that greater trading costs when buying and selling assets would reduce expected net returns. Later studies considered a liquidity factor as a systematic exposure that may be priced. Empirical studies identified a systematic liquidity factor—commonality of returns for assets with high "illiquidity betas"—and showed that both the illiquidity characteristic and the liquidity factor appear to be priced. This is not surprising given that sudden liquidity droughts tend to coincide with bad times. These illiquidity-related premia appear to raise the expected returns of certain alternative asset classes as well as less liquid pockets of traditional asset classes, such as corporate bonds and small-cap equities. Illiquidity premia are hardly constant over time; they apparently were bid down to near zero by early 2007 and then rose sky high during the 2008 liquidity drought.

# Disagreement and information asymmetries

Another CAPM assumption—homogeneous expectations—is obviously unrealistic, but this was a very convenient modeling device. In the past decade, disagreement models showed how differences in investor beliefs can influence financial markets through several channels: gradual information flow, limited attention, and heterogeneous views. Disagreement is especially important for explaining the high level of trading volume, but it also can help explain correlation or volatility risk premia as well as some cross-sectional patterns in equity returns. For example, high levels of disagreement and short-selling constraints together predict relatively low equity returns because overvalued stocks cannot be shorted and tend to be held by the most optimistic investors.

Asymmetric information refers to situations in which one party is better informed than the other, leading to so-called principal-agent problems (including moral hazard, adverse selection, conflict of interest). Vayanos-Woolley (2010) show that delegated asset management can cause momentum patterns. As investors (principals) try to learn about a manager's (agent's) skill from his past performance and effectively chase returns, the resulting fund flows push prices away from fair values, inducing short-term momentum and long-term reversal patterns.

# 5.3 DETOUR: A BRIEF SURVEY OF THE EFFICIENT MARKETS HYPOTHESIS

Before turning to behavioral finance, it is appropriate to briefly survey the efficient markets hypothesis (EMH). The classic statement from Fama (1970) is that markets are informationally efficient if "prices reflect all available information". The EMH is also closely tied to the assumption of investor rationality.

The main practical implication of the EMH is investors' inability to consistently beat the market. Why? Competition among many profit-seeking agents eliminates any easy pickings. Active management is a zero-sum game even before costs; after trading costs and fees it is a negative-sum game (this observation is mathematically true regardless of whether the market is efficient). Empirical analyses unequivocally confirm that most managers underperform passive indices after fees and leave open the possibility that winners have just been lucky. People's innate optimism and the financial industry's marketing machines have been able to muddle these messages, thereby slowing the lure of passive investing.

In its early years, the EMH was often equated with the random walk hypothesis (RWH). The ideas are closely linked. According to the RWH, aggressive competition among market participants to exploit any predictable patterns makes price changes fully random and unpredictable. All news is instantly incorporated into market prices. However, the EMH allows time variation in rational risk premia whereas the RWH assumes the special case of constant expected returns. Thus, evidence of return predictability only rejects the RWH—not the EMH. More generally, Fama stresses that only a joint hypothesis of market efficiency and a particular asset-pricing model is testable. If the joint hypothesis is rejected it can reflect the failure of either part. Indeed, Fama raised the possibility of time-varying expected returns (return predictability) even before the empirical studies of Shiller and others challenged the joint hypothesis of EMH and constant expected returns.

Grossman-Stiglitz (1980) pointed out that in the presence of information-gathering and trading costs, markets cannot be perfectly efficient. Some degree of inefficiency is needed to motivate information gathering and trading. A variation on this theme notes that general overconfidence may lead to more information gathering than is cost-effective and thus to markets that are more efficient than is economically warranted. A practical compromise argues that although markets are not quite efficient, it is so difficult to beat the market that for most investors it is best to act as if they were efficient.

One interesting newcomer is Andrew Lo's adaptive markets hypothesis (2004), which begins to apply evolutionary and ecological principles to financial markets. So far, it is not a disciplined theory but a collection of interesting ideas, such as the following. Market relationships are inherently less stable than fixed physical laws. Human interactions, such as market participants' copying successful strategies, lead to complex feedback effects. Asset prices may thus reflect the number and nature of investor groups in the market ecology. Greater competition in one area will deplete profits but also reduce the population, thereby reducing the competition and possibly starting a new cycle of renewed profitability. Aggregate risk preferences will vary with the relative sizes and preferences of various groups in the market ecology. Recent market experiences will, through natural selection, influence the current investor population's composition and aggregate risk preferences. Lo argues that various apparently irrational behavioral traits could reflect our ancestral behavior having not yet had time to adapt to modern contexts, so that individuals adapt to a changing environment through simple, and ultimately incorrect and unprofitable, heuristics (such as naive extrapolation of the recent past).

My take is that changing ecology tends to make markets more efficient over time—although not in a straight line, as the experience of 2008 shows. Active market participation has shifted from individuals to institutions and, among institutions, from traditional managers to hedge funds. Combined with the computer/Internet revolution, these shifts seem to raise the relative size of the smart money share in the ecology and thus the level of competitiveness and market efficiency. As a result of growing arbitrage capital and leverage, markets probably grew more microefficient before 2008, while arguably becoming macro-inefficient, given the broad underpricing of risks [11]. In 2007–2009, risk aversion returned with a vengeance. Amidst de-leveraging and dwindling arbitrage capital, micro-inefficiencies (relative mispricings) ballooned and expected macro-risk premia shifted quickly from historic lows to multi-decade highs.

# Recent criticism of the EMH

Besides "anomalies" (patterns of return predictability that are not easily explained by rational models), the crash of 1987, the 1999-2002 tech bubble and bust, and the 2006-2009 boom-bust period have been major challenges to the EMH. In 2008-2009 some critics went further and blamed the EMH for being one cause of the crisis. They blamed widespread belief in the EMH, and more loosely "market fundamentalism", for the laissez faire attitude of policymakers and regulators: letting leverage and asset booms grow unchecked and allowing ever more complex financial instruments and questionable sales practices flourish without restraint, under the cover that the market would inevitably get the prices of these securities right. Other criticisms come as though out of a scattergun: some attack the classical notion that competitive markets are inherently self-stabilizing, others blame the Fed's asymmetric policy responses, while others fault the use of normal distribution and VaR-based risk management in a world where fat tails dominate. All of these criticisms are only tangentially related to the EMH, yet some of the critics do not seem to realize that.

To me, a fair conclusion is that recent events have undermined the validity of the EMH's main idea—that market prices are always "right" (near the fair value)—but have underlined the validity of its main implication for most investors—that beating the markets is extremely difficult (no free lunches).

It is ironic that while the EMH is seen as one scapegoat for the 2008 crisis, behavioral finance has survived unscathed, with its reputation even enhanced. On this topic critics apparently focus on policymakers' and regulators' apparent faith in the EMH, while ignoring the mistakes made by banks and investors. If the financial industry carried an academic banner in recent decades, it was certainly not for the EMH but for behavioral finance, given the promise that the latter holds for profit-making opportunities.

Critics of the EMH often use as a straw man the most extreme version of the hypothesis, a version that not even the most ardent proponents of the EMH subscribe to any more, if they ever did. Although the EMH paradigm has faced a vigorous challenge from behavioral finance, there is no doubt that the EMH has been a powerful organizing principle for theoretical and empirical work in finance that has improved our understanding of asset returns.

# 5.4 NOTES

[1] It is perhaps useful for intuition to rearrange equation (5.1) to show that  $1 +$  Expected return  $=$  Expected future cash flows  $\div$  Their current cost (market price). This is only a linear approximation, however, if expected returns are uncertain. I ignore nonlinear "Jensen's inequality" terms throughout this book because their empirical impact tends to be small.

[2] This sensitivity or "beta" is the simple regression coefficient of asset returns on market returns (typically the U.S. equity market). It is also the ratio of the covariance of an asset with the market to the variance of the market itself, and under CAPM assumptions it measures the asset's marginal contribution to portfolio risk. Covariance between an asset and the market is the correlation between the two, multiplied by the standard deviation of both the asset and the market.

[3] Here is a more modern statement of CAPM's key insight (Campbell, 2000, p. 1515): "If all investors are single-period mean variance optimizers, then the market portfolio is mean variance efficient, which implies a beta-pricing relation between all assets and the market portfolio." This formulation stresses the mean variance efficiency of market portfolios and a consequent linear risk-reward relation. It leaves open the specification of the unobservable market portfolio. Most of the empirical work on CAPM has focused on the U.S. equity market as its proxy. The market portfolio was later broadened to include global equities and other risky asset classes.

[4] In the rational framework, the expected return equation (5.2) can be extended to include multiple risk factors, possibly with time-varying amounts or prices of risk. Irrational stories may be better viewed in the context of equation (5.1), with a distinction between the market price and a perceived fair price. The market price can exceed the fair price if investors are overoptimistic when predicting future cash flows or excessively complacent, requiring insufficient compensation for risk (too low a discount rate). The perceived fair price may be based on a valuation model or an active discretionary view.

[5] Wonkish: Equation (5.3) requires very weak assumptions. The existence of an SDF (pricing kernel) that relates payoffs to market prices for all assets follows from the absence of arbitrage opportunities. Further assumptions about the economy's structure produce more specific results than equation (5.3). For example, the SDF can be related to the marginal utility of consumption—as discussed in the main text—or asset returns can be described by a linear factor model—including single-factor models' CAPM (equity market return as the only risk factor) or consumption CAPM (aggregate consumption growth rate as the only risk factor). If we assume a linear relation between the SDF and the market return (plus the existence of a riskless asset), we get CAPM.

General equilibrium models make assumptions about preferences and production technology to derive optimal asset demands. In equilibrium, expected returns adjust until all wealth is invested in the production processes. Most equilibrium models ignore the production side by assuming an exchange economy with one consumption good and then focus on the preferences of a representative agent who maximizes the expected utility of lifetime consumption. The prototypical case involves time-separable utility (only current and future consumption matter, not past consumption) and constant relative risk aversion (the same proportion of wealth is invested in the risky asset at all wealth levels). In equilibrium, asset prices are set so that the consumer holds all the assets (market clearing) and is indifferent to buying or selling a small unit of any asset. Such optimizing behavior implies the fundamental valuation equation (5.3), that asset price is equal to the expected product of a future payoff and the SDF.

[6] A common formal specification assumes a representative agent and time-separable utility of consumption. Then the SDF equals an impatience factor times a ratio of MU next period over MU today (where MU is the marginal utility of one additional unit of consumption). The latter ratio is called the intertemporal marginal rate of substitution—the rate at which investors are willing to substitute one unit of consumption today for one unit of consumption next period. This relation determines the theoretical level of the real riskless rate.

[7] A caveat is in order. Safe haven characteristics can be unstable, like other correlations. Government bonds have been excellent safe haven assets since the late 1990s, but they were anything but safe havens during the inflationary recessions of the 1970s (see Chapter 7).

[8] One interesting newcomer is "An alternative three-factor model" by Chen-Novy-Marx-Zhang (2010). Loosely motivated by Tobin's  $q$ -theory, the authors use three factors: the market, corporate investment (return gap between stocks with a low and high investment/ assets ratio), and return on assets (return gap between stocks with a high and low return on assets). The model can better explain a wide spectrum of cross-sectional anomalies than the Fama-French model.

[9] Actually the Campbell-Cochrane model uses "external habit" for tractability reasons: People adapt to general living standards rather than to their personal experience ("internal habit"). This idea is known as "keeping up with the Joneses" and is consistent with evidence that peer comparisons matter hugely for happiness, perhaps more than actual wealth levels. As an aside, smart happiness researchers note from an evolutionary perspective that humans are not designed to be happy but to pursue happiness—including wealth and status. Unfortunately, such a pursuit partly promotes unhappiness. Discontent with our current lot gives us the drive for absolute and relative success—an evolutionarily useful trait. However, setting (unrealistically) high expectations and choosing (too) challenging peer benchmarks raise the bar but also lead to frequent disappointments.

[10] Cochrane (2007) argues that discount rate variation emphasizes the role of the average investor compared with the marginal investor, who is central in neoclassical finance models. The elusive marginal investor (often a smart arbitrageur) sets asset prices when new information arrives and modest, if any, new positions are needed to move the asset price to a new equilibrium that incorporates the new information. In contrast, discount rates (factor risk premia) reflect the average demands of all investors. The market's expected return for an asset reflects a wealth-weighted average of its participants' expected returns. Thus, if one systematic factor has a too high risk premium, the average investor needs to change his behavior and make this risk more widely shared. Since this process may be slow, markets can maintain segmented risk premia for a long time. However, hedge funds are speeding up this process of arbitrating away any attractive risk premium opportunities.

[11] Microefficiency refers to the efficient relative pricing of assets. In contrast, macro-inefficiency refers to mispricing in the aggregate level of risky assets (say, the stock market) that may be harder to battle because of the undiversifiable nature of the mispricing and the risk that it might worsen.
