# 6

# Behavioral finance

- Behavioral finance states that investor irrationality causes systematic mispricings that rational arbitrageurs cannot fully offset due to scarce capital and riskiness of "arbitrage".
- Irrationality reflects biased beliefs (heuristic shortcuts, such as representativeness and conservatism, and self-deception, such as overconfidence and hindsight) as well as nonclassical preferences (loss aversion, narrow framing, overweighting low-probability events, etc.).
- Behavioral finance literature is fun and offers stories for most observed empirical anomalies, perhaps too easily.
- The best known market-level mispricings are speculative bubbles—related to extrapolative expectations, overconfidence, and herding. The best known relative mispricings are value and momentum effects. There is an alternative rational explanation for each of these—and it is often impossible to discriminate empirically between the rational and irrational alternatives.
- Behavioral finance is often used as justification for active management. Yet, the limits-to-arbitrage literature stresses how difficult it is to exploit mispricings over any sustained time period.

Behavioral finance rests on two pillars:

(i) Some investors are irrational. Their biased beliefs and preferences influence their demand for assets and can move market prices, causing mispricings.

(ii) Various limits to arbitrage prevent rational arbitrageurs from fully offsetting the impact that such irrational investors have on market prices.

Before describing investor psychology (sources of behavioral biases), I start with the limits to arbitrage to show that psychology matters. Then I review financial market applications—speculative bubbles and other market inefficiencies—and try to link them to their psychological foundations.

# 6.1 LIMITS TO ARBITRAGE

Behavioral finance argues that certain anomalous asset-pricing patterns—where market prices appear to deviate from fundamental values—can be explained by the presence of irrational traders. Experimental studies show evidence of various behavioral biases that could influence investors' demand for a given asset. Moreover, these biases appear to be systematic—perhaps due to their evolutionary origins—so they would not cancel out across investors. However, a powerful early counterargument by Milton Friedman (1953) was that rational traders will view any such mispricings as trading opportunities and by taking advantage of market dislocations they will undo any price impact irrational traders might have. This argument sounds especially compelling in today's world with thousands of hedge funds "on the job" competing exactly for such opportunities. Yet a sequence of papers from the late 1980s to Shleifer-Vishny (1997), dubbed the limits-to-arbitrage literature, argue convincingly that arbitrage is both risky and costly, so that arbitrageurs, at least in many cases, do not have enough capacity to fully counter the impact of irrational ("noise") traders. The Long-Term Capital Management (LTCM) crisis in 1998—more than a year after the Shleifer and Vishny article came out—followed the script so closely that it showered real-world credibility on these arguments. If further supportive evidence was needed, the next decade provided it in spades.

Noise trader models assume two types of traders—rational arbitrageurs ("smart money"), and noise traders (mere mortals) whose sentiment and asset demands can irrationally change over time. If irrational demand from noise traders moves prices away from their fundamental values, arbitrageurs will try to exploit the mispricing and bring prices back to fundamentals. However, arbitrage strategies that are designed to correct mispricing can be risky, limiting their use.

Arbitrage is only riskless in the extreme case of perfect substitutability and frictionless markets. Most real-world "arbitrage" opportunities deserve quotation marks because they are only "good deals" that can move against the arbitrageur. With micro-inefficiencies where good substitutes (highly correlated assets) exist, arbitrageurs can put on relative value trades so that some of the risk in arbitrage is hedged. With macroindeficiencies (say, a market bubble) without good asset substitutes, such hedging is not possible, so the arbitrating of market-level mispricing is risky and unattractive.

Arbitrageurs face both the fundamental risk of adverse news and the "noise trader risk" of the possibility that sentiment will make mispricing worse. If arbitrageurs have longer horizons than noise traders, they can be more aggressive and can "ride out" temporary mispricings.

Noise trader risk is exacerbated when arbitrageurs manage other people's money and face the risk of capital withdrawals. In reality, such delegated fund management is typical for arbitrageurs (such as hedge funds). The use of outside investor funding increases the likelihood that the arbitrageur has to liquidate his position at the worst possible time. The agency relation means that end-customers are more likely to withdraw capital just when mispricing trades have moved maximally against the arbitrageur. End-customers assess an arbitrageur's ability by studying performance track records; and widening mispricing normally implies deteriorating performance for the arbitrageur. To compound the arbitrageurs' problems when they are facing losses, creditors may make margin calls if leverage is employed, stop-loss rules or risk managers can require position reductions, and vanishing liquidity may reinforce the downward spiral. All these considerations push arbitrageurs toward short time horizons and constrain their position sizes. There are also transaction costs and model uncertainty to consider. Trading costs on leveraged strategies can be significant. Barring remarkable hubris, no arbitrageur can be completely confident that his model or view is correct.

One important implication for long-horizon institutional investors is that when they delegate asset management, external managers may not inherit the ultimate investor's long horizon. Principal-agent problems shorten horizons from both sides, a phenomenon that can make the long-horizon investor lose his natural edge.

Market turmoil in 1998 and 2007-2008 taught us additional features that should discourage arbitrage activities—VaR-based risk management and crowded trade risk:

- Risk management systems that make sense for any one investor can increase systemic risk. A vicious circle can arise when rising risks (in VaR models or in other reactive risk measures) trigger mandatory or voluntary position reductions (but the problem is much worse if mandatory); widespread liquidations can destabilize the markets and require further reductions. Procyclical regulatory capital requirements have a similar impact.
- If many leveraged arbitrageurs have similar positions, the desire of some of them to liquidate positions can cause a rush to the exit that makes even fundamentally unrelated positions move temporarily in lockstep—against the arbitrageurs. Smart strategies may thus have more "crowding risk" than popular naive strategies. Downside correlations are often higher than normal correlations, especially for "smart" trades that appear to offer a favorable long-run reward to risk. Indeed, there may now exist an endogenous systematic risk factor associated with crowded trades.

The limits-to-arbitrage literature has been highly influential:

- It explains why behavioral biases can leave a large footprint in the market even in a world filled with opportunistic hedge funds. It even suggests which types of mispricings are less susceptible to attracting arbitrage—notably, those where mispriced assets lack close substitutes, where mispricings correct slowly, or where perceived model uncertainty is high.
- It stresses that even in inefficient markets there may be no free lunches. Thus the well-documented difficulty of beating the market does not necessarily imply that market prices equal fundamental values.
- The literature has broadened to study more generally the role of financial institutions and agency costs. The impediments to arbitrage include diverse risks as well as capital, leverage, and margin constraints.
- I use the terms "investor irrationality" and "market inefficiency" interchangeably because the former is often thought to imply the latter. This is only true given limited arbitrage; otherwise the actions of a few smart arbitrageurs would undo the price dislocations caused by many irrational traders.

# 6.2 PSYCHOLOGY

Experimental studies reveal systematic biases in people's judgments as well as systematic deviations from the preferences implied by the rational expected utility paradigm. I review some main behavioral biases before turning to their possible impact on asset prices.

All these psychological features are underpinnings of the developing theory of investor sentiment—how real-world investors actually form their beliefs, preferences, and demand schedules for assets. This second foundation of behavioral finance is still much patchier, and less coherent, than the limits-to-arbitrage literature but, in a sense, this is where the meat is.

# 6.2.1 Biases

# 6.2.1.1 Heuristic simplifications

Evolutionary logic is most obvious with heuristics. Humans have limited attention, memory, and information-processing capacities. Given our limited cognitive resources, we cannot analyze the world around us optimally. Instead, heuristics—rules of thumb or mental shortcuts—have evolved to help us select subsets of available information that are believed to be the most relevant. Recent psychological and neuro-finance research suggest that we humans have two models of probabilistic assessment that work in different parts of the brain: system I thinking (quick heuristics, intuition) and system II thinking (deliberative rational reasoning). System I mechanisms are much older; they evolved to help humans survive the most important challenges faced in the prehistoric environment. These inherited mechanisms can still help us cope in the more complex modern world but they can also lead to systematic errors, including some that can cost us money. The evolutionary character of this argument also suggests that people share similar heuristics; biases are not whims that average out across different individuals.

These fascinating ideas are elaborated on in Hirshleifer (2001), Montier (2007), and Zweig (2008).

# Attention and memory biases

Selective attention on easily accessible information causes availability bias. We are more likely to recall—and overweight—information that is salient, vivid, attention grabbing, familiar, emotionally hitting, or simply more recent. We also like stories; we want to understand complex events through simple narratives. These biases distort our probability and frequency judgments.

# Representativeness

Representativeness is the phenomenon by which people rely too much on stereotypes instead of cold probability analysis. People who judge the probability of an outcome based on how similar it is to the stereotype of the perceived true process tend to ignore sample size and neglect "base-rate" information. (Base-rate neglect refers to the tendency to misappraise the frequency of an event in a relevant population. The classic example is that based on a brief characterization—a quiet older woman wearing glasses—people guess that the person described is a librarian because she resembles a stereotypical librarian; information about the relative scarcity of librarians in the population is neglected.) They also expect each data sample to reflect the salient characteristics of the underlying true process. This misconception causes them to be surprised if they see a random series appear to exhibit trends and can make them see patterns in truly random sequences, leading to extrapolation where none is justified. The evolutionary origin of extrapolation is obvious: humans are hardwired to mimic visibly successful solutions to problems because such imitation enhanced our distant ancestors' survival prospects.

# Box 6.1. Extrapolation and reversal tendencies

Shefrin (2002) discusses evidence that individual investors tend to extrapolate (predict trend continuation) while professional managers and strategists tend to predict reversals. Why this difference? And can we really claim that both biases are caused by representativeness?

- People use representativeness to form a judgment about the most likely true process from which the sample they observe is generated and then make predictions based on this perceived true process. People often mistakenly assume that small samples should feature the same essential properties as the true process. (This error is called "the law of small numbers.") For example, although runs of five or six tails are quite possible in a coin-flipping exercise with a fair coin (which is a random walk process with 50/50 odds), people erroneously think that such runs should be extremely rare in a truly random process. Thus, if people know the coin is fair and see a small sample with four or five successive tails, they may think "heads is due" and predict a reversal, to make the sequence look more representative (the gambler's fallacy). However, if people don't know for sure that the true process is 50/50 (fair coin, random walk) they often make the opposite mistake—they use representativeness to infer the process from which the small sample is drawn. In the example with a run of tails, they see something that resembles a trending process so they decide that the true process is trending and predict trend continuation, implicitly or explicitly concluding (against actual evidence) that the coin is unfair.
- Which effect dominates? Availability bias helps distinguish between settings where people become excessively prone to make reversal or continuation predictions. If the true process is salient (e.g., flipping a fair coin), reversal error is common, whereas if the true process is unknown, people extrapolate too much. Real-world financial markets are often characterized by ambiguity, so it is no wonder that individual investors tend to "see trends" and over-extrapolate. Professional investors are better educated about the (near) random walk behavior of asset prices and thus are more confident about the 50/50 process, which makes them more prone to committing the gambler's fallacy.
- Perhaps a broader lesson is that settings with greater uncertainty about the true process (e.g., new assets, limited data, lack of valuation anchors) make investors more prone to extrapolation and markets thus more susceptible to trending (momentum) and to overreactions.

# Conservatism

Conservatism is the tendency of people to underweight new evidence when they update their priors (e.g., by giving insufficient attention to new public data). Anchoring and adjustment is another related bias that can contribute to underweighting new evidence. When people make predictions, they start from some initial value (anchor)—one that can be quite arbitrary if no relevant information is available—and then adjust it to get a final prediction. Such adjustments are typically insufficient and leave final predictions biased toward the anchor.

# Box 6.2. How to reconcile the apparent contradiction in representativeness and conservatism stories

If prior beliefs are viewed as base rate information, conservatism implies overweighting base rate information (and underreacting to new data) whereas representativeness implies base rate neglect (and overreacting to new data). Griffin-Tversky (1992) propose a theory that explains the coexistence of conservatism and representativeness effects. Their thesis is that when making forecasts, people pay too much attention to the strength of the information and too little to its statistical weight, relative to a rational Bayesian investor. (I explain this thesis in greater detail below.) Whether the market underreacts or overreacts to new signals, then, depends on the application setting—in particular, the nature of new information.

- Each piece of information can be judged along two dimensions—strength and weight. Strength is tied to the salience and extremity of the evidence while weight is tied to its statistical reliability, including sample size. For a funny illustration, you are reading a glowing letter of recommendation for a job candidate you are about to hire—and infer a very strong message. However, when you realize that the letter is signed by the candidate's mother, the weight of its informativeness is deflated.
- Conservatism arises in the face of evidence that has low strength but a high weight (e.g., a sample that is large relative to the population); people underreact to such evidence even though the high weight would justify a stronger reaction. On the other hand, representativeness arises when evidence has high strength but low weight (e.g., people "see" a short trend); people pay excessive attention to salient evidence and overreact to it.
- The literature on representativeness and conservatism also suggests the following: people tend to overreact to salient events, concrete anecdotes, good stories, and extreme realizations. They underreact to abstract statistical information, such as sample size or predictive ability, as well as remote events. People often underweight changes in a series unless recent changes are prominent and attributable to a clear cause. If people can associate an observed new data sample with a salient past event or model or, even better, their personal experience, they overweight the new data (representativeness); otherwise, people rely too little on the data and too much on their priors (conservatism). One-time strong news events are likely to generate more overreaction than a sequence of smaller events. Given overconfidence, people probably overreact more easily to private signals (their own research, word of mouth) than to public news. A possible exception: Price trends may be especially attention grabbing, even if they are very public information.

# 6.2.1.2 Self-deception (overconfidence and limits to learning)

There are certain evolutionary benefits in being overconfident. In general, confidence and optimism may give a person energy to strive for challenging goals and may result in more success, happiness, and even longer life. Excessive confidence has some downsides

(e.g., may lead to frequent disappointments) and there is some debate among psychologists about the net benefit. Appearances are especially important for this argument—those able to appear smart and strong are more likely to attract mates and pass on their genes. Self-deception is a part of the story because it is easier to appear competent if you believe in yourself. Overconfident people tend to fail more often than they expect to but nature has provided them with various other biases that help them ignore such feedback and maintain their overconfidence.

# Overconfidence

Overconfidence is a well-documented bias in many contexts. Most of us feel we are above average when it comes to sense of humor, intelligence, car-driving skills, and many other contexts. We also think that we are less prone to behavioral biases than others. (I do, don't you?) Being an expert does not help. More knowledge may even be harmful as it often raises our confidence more than our forecasting ability. Experts in most professions are prone to overconfidence—typically more so than laymen when predictability is low and evidence ambiguous, making feedback inconclusive. Financial professionals are particularly overconfident.

Overconfidence is one key reason for excessive trading volumes but it may also contribute to several asset-pricing regularities. Overconfident investors assign too much weight to information and analysis that they collect or produce themselves, while underweighting public information. The tendency to disregard public information may explain investor underreaction to corporate news, while the high weight placed on one's own experience may contribute to observed momentum and reversal patterns as explained below.

# Overoptimism

Overoptimism is related to both overconfidence in one's own abilities and to wishful thinking. "The future will be great, especially for me." Optimists are prone to an illusion of control; they underrate the role of randomness and they underestimate risks.

# Biased self-attribution

People tend to attribute good outcomes to their own abilities (skill) and bad outcomes to external circumstances (bad luck). This feature feeds overconfidence when people succeed and inhibits learning when people fail. Thus it enables self-deception rather than accurate self-assessment.

# Confirmation bias

We seek evidence that supports our view and we interpret ambiguous evidence as supportive.

# Hindsight bias

Hindsight makes past outcomes, even major surprises, appear virtually inevitable after the fact. ("The market crash was bound to happen.") More personally, memories play tricks on us: we often recall that we had assigned a high likelihood to events that subsequently materialized. ("I knew all along that housing was overpriced.") Hindsight reinforces overconfidence but may also cause regret. By making the past appear more predictable than it really was, hindsight bias fools us into seeing the future as more predictable than it can ever be. Thus the inevitable disappointments that befall investors from time to time are seen, mistakenly, as having been avoidable. The financial media seem especially prone to hindsight and they promote it among the public. Investors underappreciate the degree to which chance (randomness) determines observed outcomes—and this misconception partly explains why active management is so popular, despite its poor record.

# 6.2.2 Preferences

Traditional decision theory analyzes choices between uncertain gambles, the simplest of which are characterized by two possible outcomes and their associated probabilities. People form beliefs, or make judgments, about the probabilities; they assign values, or utilities, to outcomes; and they combine beliefs and values to make decisions. Preferences, in particular attitudes toward risk (quantified as the chooser's degree of risk aversion), determine what choices people make among the various opportunities that exist, given their beliefs. Traditional theory says that people calculate the expected utility of each gamble as the probability-weighted sum of utility outcomes, then choose the gamble with the highest expected utility. This theory has dominated neoclassical economics and finance, but experimental work has found substantial violations of this rational model, leading to the development of various alternative theories. The most famous behavioral alternative is prospect theory (PT).

# Prospect theory

In PT, Kahneman-Tversky (1979) developed an intentionally positive, or descriptive, model of preferences that would best characterize the deviations of actual choices ("what do people really do?") from the normative expected utility model ("what should rational people do?"). It seems likely that PT's key ideas have evolutionary origins in that they reflect quick and intuitive reasoning. The main findings of PT, as revealed in Kahneman and Tversky's experimental studies, are:

—people care more about gains and losses (changes in wealth) than about overall wealth;

- people exhibit loss aversion and can be risk seeking when facing the possibility of loss;
- people overweight low-probability events.

Here is a well-known example from behavioral experiments:

1. Suppose that you are paid 1,000 to participate in a gamble that presents you with the following further choices:

(1A) a sure 500 gain;

 (1B) a 50\% chance of winning \$1,000, a 50\% chance of \$0.

2. Suppose that you are paid 2,000 to participate in a gamble that presents you with the following further choices:

(2A) a sure 500 loss;

 (2B) a 50\% chance of losing \$1,000, a 50\% chance of \$0.

The typical strategies chosen in these situations are (1A) (certainty) and (2B) (risk seeking), even though the total wealth outcomes in (1A) and (2A) are identical (you gain 1,500 overall), and the total wealth outcomes in (1B) and (2B) are likewise identical. People act as if they are risk averse when only gains are involved but become risk seeking when facing the possibility of loss and they view the initial bonus and the gamble separately. Such findings, together with the observation that people tend to reject actuarially fair (50/50) gambles, point to loss aversion (losses loom larger than same-sized gains) [1].

Let us look at the specifics. In PT, people maximize the weighted sum of values (utilities) where weights are not probabilities themselves (using the probabilities would be rational) but their nonlinear transformations:

- Whether an outcome is seen as a gain or a loss determines the value (utility) of a dollar (as shown in Figure 6.1a). In other words, a dollar is not worth a dollar; its value depends on the context. The focus on gains and losses rather than on overall wealth is consistent with evaluating each gamble in isolation. If people naturally took into account their whole wealth when considering the offered gambles, they would not reject actuarially advantageous gambles as often as they do.
- The value function is kinked at the origin or the "reference point"; the steeper slope below zero implies loss aversion. Many studies show that losses hurt twice to two and a half times as much as same-sized gains satisfy. Following the example above, the value function has concave (convex) shape to the right (left) of the reference point, implying risk aversion among gambles that involve only gains but risk seeking among gambles that involve only losses.
- Overweighting low-probability events is the main feature of the probability-weighting function (Figure 6.1b). This feature explains the simultaneous demand for both lotteries and insurance, a real-world phenomenon that has puzzled economists who assume rationality. Such overweighting of small probabilities can be strong enough to reverse the sign of risk appetite in the value function. Lotteries that offer a small chance of very large gains can induce risk seeking, despite a general tendency to risk aversion when gambles only involve gains. Conversely, people dislike low-probability large-impact losses so much that they pay up for insurance to avoid such losses (thus implying risk aversion), despite the general risk-seeking tendency that appears when gambles only involve losses [2].

PT simply postulates the leaning S shape of the value function. Novel research proposes an alternative foundation based on salience while using standard risk preferences. According to Bordalo-Gennaioli-Shleifer (2010), decision-makers overweight the likelihood of salient states (where lotteries have extreme, contrasting payoffs), and this can explain both the reflecting shape of the value function and the overweighting of low-probability events. The authors stress that investors only overweight salient low-probability events—a point that may resolve the tension between PT and the idea that black-swan-type low-probability events, events that investors think are nigh impossible or do not think about at all, are underweighted.

PT itself does not generate many testable predictions. It needs to be combined with other assumptions, such as narrow framing or the house money effect (as discussed below).
